  [0mAll: before reading further, make sure you're up on the site guidelines and don't post political or
  [0mideological flames to this thread. If you're hot under the collar, please cool down and wait for your
  [0mcuriosity to come back before commenting (and maybe even reading) further. This is a good test case to see if
  [0mHN can stick to its intended spirit: [34mnews.ycombinator.com/newsguidelines.html[0m

  [0m
  [0mAs many have pointed out, a dozen or so submissions on this topic were flagged by users. That's actually the
  [0mimmune system working as intended, but another component of the system is that moderators rescue the very most
  [0mhistoric stories so HN can have a single big thread about them. We did that 4 years ago, also for Brexit,
  [0metc.
  [0m
  [0mSince this was the first submission on the topic, it seems fairest to be the one to restore. (It's still on
  [0mour todo list to have some form of karma sharing for situations like this, to make it be less of a race and/or
  [0mlottery.)
  [0m
  [0mI changed the URL from [34mwww.cnn.com/[0m since that is not the most useful link and the AP seems as close as one
  [0mcan get to a neutral source.
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

  [1mdorkwood[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0m¼ There's a famous optical illusion ½ with a spinning silhouette of a dancer. When you ¾, look at it, you'll
  [0mswear it's spinning in one direction — say, counter-clockwise. In fact, you'll be so sure it's spinning
  [0mcounter-clockwise, that the idea it could be spinning in the opposite direction will seem impossible to you.
  [0mBut if you stare at it long enough, and intently enough, you can make it spin the other way.
  [0m
  [0mI've noticed the same phenomenon with political views.
  [0m
  [0mPeople on the left think that anyone on the right is a lunatic, and everyone on the right thinks the same
  [0mthing about the left. I, as most people do, lean in one direction politically, so naturally any comment I see
  [0mcoming from my side seems reasonable to me. In fact, it seems impossible that a reasonable person could think
  [0many other way. But since I grew up in a family that leaned in the opposite direction, and I shared their same
  [0mmindset in my younger days, I can now draw on that experience, and I can take a political tweet that everyone
  [0mon my side thinks is insane, and I can stare at it, and just as with the spinning dancer, I can flip it in my
  [0mhead so it seems reasonable.
  [0m
  [0mTo me, it's a testament to the power of the tribal instincts within us. We think it's the other side that's
  [0mcrazy, but we're all under the same spell. ⅙

                                                  [1m▶ 101 replies[0m                                                 ‌

   [1mpqhwan[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mGrowing up in a country where I was in the ethnic majority, I went through a period of right-wing political⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbent as a teenager. Then I came to the US, where I found myself in the minority and leaning left. So I feel⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat I have some personal insight into the mindset that pushes people right. But… maybe it’s that my past⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mright-leaning self was a teenager with half-baked ideas about the world, when I reflect on what drove me that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mway, I cannot point to any coherent, constructive thought, mostly feelings of entitlement and an⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0munwillingness to put myself in the other’s shoes. And that’s what I see in the right-wing of today in the US.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI guess I empathize with their fear and anger better because of my experience, but I don’t buy that their⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0marguments are just a “different” way of looking at the world; a narrower, myopic way, maybe.⁣

   [1mnamuol[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe difference is that with the spinning dancer optical illusion, there's never a "wrong" way to view it.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThis isn't always the case with politics, or any kind of view for that matter. It's important to empathize⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwith people you disagree with, but it's just as important that we start with a foundation of agreed upon⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfacts.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIn other words, reality isn't a point of view.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mprobably_wrong[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mit's just as important that we start with a foundation of agreed upon facts. In other words, reality isn't[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3ma point of view.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI don't think these two things are as strongly related as you suggest. Two reasonable people can look at the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msame problem with the same facts, make reasonable guesses on what the best course is, and yet reach two⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcompletely different, [3mreasonable[0m approaches to the problem. Otherwise, we would have already decided which⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mprogramming language is the best one.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mSome situations are more clear cut than others, and I agree that we need to separate facts from opinion⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbetter. But for situations as complex as the present and future of a country there might very well not be a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m"right" way.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m"Reality" is not a point of view, but we only experience it through the lens of our personal experiences. No⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mone experiences "true" reality.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mroenxi[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mApologies in advance if this sounds snappy, this hits an issue I feel strongly about.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mMy local supermarket has precisely no empathy for me and the only thing I expect to agree on with the local⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mstore manager is price. Yet it is by far the most effective conduit for getting me cheap food. Effective⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msystems simply are not very good at empathy and agreement on non-core issues is unimportant. Empathy in⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mparticular recommended at a personal level but not especially useful in politics. The critical tool is the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mability to comprehend, negotiate, compromise and articulate why things are necessary.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHaving "empathy" for "the left"/"the right" isn't possible. The groups are too large and diverse. Ditto for⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmajor components of the left or right like "the black vote", "the evangelicals", "people in cities", "people⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfrom Detroit", "the wealthy", etc, etc. Entities that you can have empathy for or agree on facts with are⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtoo small to be politically important like individuals or families. Politics is done by large groups who's⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbeliefs are too nebulous to align.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mtempestn[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mCanada feels closer to what your parent described than to what I see in the US, for one. There are of⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcourse those at the extremes who are very partisan. Although most of those identify more with US politics⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthan Canadian it seems. But for the vast majority it's much less of an issue than it is in the US. For one⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthing, most people are not members of one of our federal political parties. Local politicians don't even⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0malign with federal parties, nor do provincial ones in all cases. Many people will shift their vote between⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mideologically similar parties, especially the Liberals and NDP.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mBasically, for myself and most people I know, we vote for the party whose platform most closely matches our⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mown priorities and beliefs, but it's not part of our identities in the same way. The parties themselves are⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0malso far less polarized than in the US. And because it's a multi-party system, you can have minority⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mgovernment that actually functions by garnering support of opposition parties. (We also effectively don't⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mhave multiple veto points though, so generally the governing party is able to govern; I think that also⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mhelps keep things from getting overheated.) Of course, the system isn't perfect. For instance by virtue of⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mbeing both multi-party and first past the post, the winning party usually has the vote of a minority of the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpopulation, and still generally holds a majority of seats in parliament. But I've really come to⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mappreciate it in comparison over the past few years.⁣
  ⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mThere is generally not just one side that has a meaningful investment in the resolution of some political⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0missue. Arguing that the other side does not have a legitimate concern regarding some political conflict is⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mgenerally not going to be very persuasive, and it isn't going to make those people go away.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mabout by means of influencing the power games of elected officials is often very crude and ineffective.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mSometimes influencing politics is necessary, but if we let ourselves believe that the only way to effect⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mchange is "shake the vending machine" of governmental power we will generally end up frustrated.⁣

    [1mjohngalt[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mscience.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mam I not, objectively speaking, correct, because my opinion on those matters are backed by science?[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIt is true that shutdowns, distancing, masking are all evidence based methods to contain the pandemic.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHowever, politics is not only about selecting what methods work, but where they are applied, and who bears⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe cost. There is rarely an objective 'backed by the science' answer across the board.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mregularfry[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mthere is not one single tribe that is objectively correct when it comes to matter of policy when, in fact,[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mthere are correct ways of deciding on policy.[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mThere's also the mental health costs of extended social distancing. These questions are not answered by⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mthat that must be settled before we can make factual determinations about policy.⁣

   [1mprossercj[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIs this not a function of how rationality actually works? We all begin with premises which are fundamentally⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0munproven and unprovable. Our conclusions follow from those premises. Change the premises and the result⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mchanges, though both sets of deductions may be perfectly rational. In other words, rationality is a process,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mnot a set of conclusions.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mOne word for this is "tradition". If I've piqued your interest, please read Alasdair MacIntyre's book "After⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mVirtue," and also it's sequel with a more provocative title, "Whose Justice? Which Rationality?"⁣
  ⁣

   [1mfuzzfactor[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe two parties provide the opposing agendas which dominate, and the particular characteristics of each⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcandidate are secondary.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEspecially when neither party has much to offer the average citizen any more, they have built their strength⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtraditionally on low voter turnout where extreme factions loudly broadcasting gradually become⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mover-represented in the most polarizing way.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAs cycles continue only the most polarizing issues drive the turnout, and for turnout to grow beyond a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcertain point the majority of the potential voters must perceive the other party as a more serious threat,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwhen compared to any security offered by their own party which they (might) have chosen because they found it⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mless offensive (maybe only in past cycles too).⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe parties no longer need to have as much to offer the average citizen as cycles go on, when they can get⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcontending turnout from their own extremists combined with orders of magnitude more sympathizers who can be⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconvinced to strongly fear what the _other side_ could take away.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSeems like after a party has been around for longer than any living person, they will not get support by⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhaving more to offer average citizens than in previous cycles, only by taking less away from them.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSo the average citizen hasn't had a positive outcome within reach for a while.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNow it's too late, these top candidates are realistically as youthful as you can get compared to the grand⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mold parties themselves, and regardless of personal integrity or leadership style can not offer anything above⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat from the parties alone.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEven in the case of Trump's extreme personality, which the Democrats did not even try to nominate a candidate⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhaving that feature, so this element was as one-sided as you can get.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI saw agreement from both sides that a wet dishrag could defeat Trump if only 270 electors represent voters⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwho just plain dislike or hate him. Conversely it was recognized Trump would win if he had merely 270⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0melectors of voters who dislike or hate one or more of the current items on the Democratic party platform.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNeither strategy can offer anything to the majority of the citizens in the political middle, the true average⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcitizen, since turnout has been driven by fear not opportunity.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mBuilding a coalition from a carefully-crafted extreme attention-getting position, and pushing hard from there⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mso the other side ends up below the 50 percent needed to be in power, has turned out to prevail over⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrepresenting even the middle 50 percent of voters which is how it was supposed to be at a minimum.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSo once the issues and/or personalities representing them have reached full polarity, 50 becomes more of a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconstant to be converged upon from afar rather than a starting point to build a majority from in both⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdirections.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mResulting in half the voters who turn out, and half the politically centrist citizens (which is a much larger⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mgroup by a variable multiple of active voters) who will always be dissatisfied and these are two different⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mgroups (but having significant overlap), the latter of which is the core of the majority that all parties are⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msupposed to be treating as constituents.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mBut the core of the majority in the middle doesn't have a voice because they don't have any party which⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrepresents them any more, the parties are doing other things with the money and the concerns of centrist⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcitizens are given lowest priority.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe party gets more votes over the long run by fear-mongering against the other side regardless of who the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcandidates are at the time, and only declining resources can be justified which might actually benefit the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmajority of citizens.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mProblem is, the majority are voting against their own best interest because their own best interest has not⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbeen available for a number of cycles. Rather each side votes against what's perveived as the other's best⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0minterest instead, since that's the only thing at stake anyway.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSo the majority of voters end up speaking for the entire population as designed, but all votes are cast⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0magainst someone's best interest because the minority party is voting exactly the same as the majority in this⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mregard.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSo it's unanimous by both parties that as few of the average citizens as possible should have their best⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0minterest be served, and to redefine democracy in that direction can not be accomplished during a single cycle⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mor maybe not even a single generation.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEnding up with the choice between a trustworthy Joe and a dishonest Don the thing that doesn't really matter⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mto half the voters as much as it should.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIt would probably help if there were parties which were younger than the candidates.⁣

  [1mablekh[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOK, so the transition from Make America Great Again slogan to Make America Decent Again (and Better) reality
  [0mis inevitable and welcome. It is easy to get overjoyed by results of the U.S. Presidential Election (and some
  [0mcelebration certainly is in order).
  [0m
  [0mUniting the country is definitely a commendable goal, though it is easier said than done. The election results
  [0macross all levels clearly illustrate just how divided and polarized this land is. Thus, it will take quite a
  [0mlot of time and effort to see a reasonable progress on this front. We all can play our part in it by a polite
  [0mand constructive dialog with opponents and first finding common ground on such pressing and all-encompassing
  [0missues as coronavirus pandemic, environmental protection, social justice and health care reform.
  [0m
  [0mIn the meantime, let us not forget that, in order to restore the heavily damaged moral fabric of this country,
  [0mrelevant measures should pass through the Congress. And while Democrats retain control of the House, the
  [0mopposing party might retain control of the Senate. Which most certainly will lead to a significant gridlock in
  [0mmoving forward with the democratic and, in some cases, progressive agenda unless Democrats retake control in
  [0mthe Senate. Remember, [3mwinning a battle is not a guarantee for winning a war[0m. That is why the U.S. Senate
  [0mrun-off elections in Georgia to be held on January 5 ([34mgeorgia.gov/vote-2020-runoff-elections[0m) are crucial.

     [1mXorNot[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mHi, I'm from Australia. Voting is mandatory here! Turn out in our elections is 99.x%. You are not obligated⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mto make a choice, but you are obligated under pain of a $30 fine to be registered at a polling station on⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0melection day. You can avoid the fine if you present a valid reason for not voting after the election when⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mnotified. Such a reason would definitely include "I was prevented from voting" or "I was threatened if I⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mvoted", and would be registered with the AEC and investigated seriously.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mOur Electoral commission is the most trusted government body in the country, and has maintained a culture⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mof independence and accuracy. We don't have any form of electronic voting, but generally have election⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mresults on election night.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mOur system has multiple viable political parties! Factions on both the left and right of the spectrum at⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmultiple government levels have successfully won and lost seats over the years depending on their ability⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mto poll within the electorate. This [3mhas not[0m resulted in them being regarded as "spoilers" to the main⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpolitical parties, and has acted at times as an effective check on government policy since it encouraged⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcross-party negotiation through multiple avenues.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIs our system perfect? No - no system is. But come election night, our representative government [3mactually[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mrepresents the people. If you got 51% of the vote, then 51% of the population, through some means, selected⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0myou as a preferred candidate.⁣
  ⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mA fetus isn't a person in the eyes of the US government. It never has been. This is an orthogonal issue to⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mhow to handle abortion in America. Conservatives believe that those who seek and provide abortion should be⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpunished, but we know that this does not result in fewer abortions. Liberals believe that we should take⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msteps to limit the need to seek the abortion in the first place.⁣

    [1mcamgunz[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m1. Separate opinion journalism from reporting journalism.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mOpinion journalism can be w/e. Reporting journalism has to be fact checked. Masquerading as reporting⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mjournalism should be a big bad. You gotta disclose opinion journalism up front, like you gotta put a Surgeon⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mGeneral's warning on cigarettes.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m2. Mandate non-partisan districting boards and do away with "safe" districts.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThis would lose majority-minority districts, which are responsible for a big proportion of our Reps of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcolor. But safe districts skyrocket partisanship; politicians in safe districts can wander super far from⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe mainstream—think Steve King for example. And actually they oftentimes have to become radical in order to⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msurvive primaries. There's only so much you can do here with the current system but, a little would help a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mlot.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m3. Empower state and local governments by repealing balanced budget amendments and term limits.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mState governments have really hamstrung themselves with these policies, and as a result the federal⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mgovernment has to do a lot. This creates a perception—right or wrong—that a far away government is telling⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0myou how to live your life. If the federal government has secured rights for all and managed federal⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mconcerns, it should be reasonable for say, Oregon to have one set of gun regulations and Illinois to have⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0manother.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m4. Make voting compulsory, make Election Day a holiday, expand early voting, establish same day registration⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0meverywhere.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe majority of Senators (and in midterms, the majority of Reps) are elected by a minority of people who are⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmuch more partisan than the mean. This pushes politicians out of the mainstream.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m5. Federally finance elections, shorten the length, and amend the Constitution to obviate [3mCitizens United[0m.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mCampaigns and their ads are super polarizing. Special interests run messaging campaigns on wedge issues⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m(abortion, immigration, gun rights) in order to pass bills like SOPA or subsidies for fossil fuel energy⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcompanies in the night. Campaign finance reform disarms all this.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m6. Limit the terms of Supreme Court Justices to 18 years and enact jurisdiction stripping.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe stakes of Supreme Court nominations are so high that it drives us all crazy. We should limit their terms⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mso that 2-term presidents get to nominate 2 Justices, and we should limit the power of the Supreme Court on⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe basis that it's a deeply undemocratic and unaccountable institution. Pro-lifers feel this every day, as⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdo progressives. We all agree it's bad; let's change it.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m7. Enact affirmative action for mortgage companies, fund housing assistance, and reform public schools.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe US has a huge de facto segregation issue due to generations of discriminatory practices by mortgage⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcompanies, and the sky high cost of housing in neighborhoods with good schools. This creates fertile ground⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfor bubbles and othering, not just in adults but also in children.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m8. Re-establish affirmative action for colleges, and make it free.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe partisanship gap in the US now largely traces the education and income gap.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m9. Establish clear boundaries on religious freedom.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mReligious freedom is a fundamental part of the fabric of the United States, but so are personal liberty and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mindividual rights. We need to give people the ability to live out their beliefs, but also establish a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpluralistic society free of discrimination towards _and from_ the religious. Fighting a culture via⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mreligious freedom debases us all.⁣
  ⁣

    [1mablekh[0m [35mPP [0m[2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe following definition that was shared by someone on Quora is quite good, though a bit academic. Moral⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfabric is [3m"a metaphor for the flexible but still assured structure of virtue that forms the basis of[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mintegrity and holds society together"[0m.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mTo put it simpler, I would define moral fabric as [3ma set of foundational moral principles (common moral[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mground) that most people in a particular society agree on and recognize as guidelines throughout their daily[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mlives[0m. These principles form a cohesive environment of values, which is referred to a moral fabric.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHere's a blog post with a potentially better definition:⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[34mnomoralfabric.wordpress.com/2012/10/29/the-loss-of-m….[0m⁣

   [1mglitcher[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIMO the saddest part of it all is that many people seem to be choosing paths of division. I have different⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfamily members who are firmly inside bubbles on both sides of the political spectrum. And all of them are way⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtoo comfortable in parroting the divisive language they hear on their favorite network news channels. The⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mterms right/left, red/blue, republican/democrat, conservative/liberal are commonly used with insulting tones⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtowards opposing sides. And when they use these broad terms they seem totally content that they have made a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mstrong argument on some issue that actually boils down to making huge over-generalizations of people, and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mover-simplifications of complex issues.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI don't accept the demonization of fellow Americans based on bad faith arguments, but I sometimes I feel like⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthis is a minority opinion. We should absolutely fight against specific events, behaviors, political⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrhetoric, and policies we disagree with. And sometimes individuals or small groups deserve to have their⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mactions demonized as completely against our values. But looking for simple labels to place on literally⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmillions of complex humans in order to point at simple answers to issues where simple answers don't exist is⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0ma fool's game.⁣

   [1mputlake[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI feel like a big reason for the divide is the filter bubbles[[31m1[0m] the public has trapped themselves in. I⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwanted to force myself to read news from both sides of the divide rather than simply NPR, which was my go-to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msource for several years. In spite of RSS readers being essentially dead, there are still RSS feeds⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mavailable. So I mashed up feeds from 10 left and right leaning sources each and created Smash the Bubble[[33m2[0m],⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmostly for personal consumption.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[[31m1[0m][34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_bubble[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[[33m2[0m][34msmashthebubble.com/[0m⁣
  ⁣
    [1mprojektfu[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI have tried to do the same, signing up for the Flip Side newsletter, among other things. I think it’s still⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhard for me, an over-educated progressive, to understand the American right. Here are the problems:⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m1. Reality is often only reported in “liberal” news sources. A lot of information is censored on right wing⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msources.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m2. Both types of news sources editorialize in the headline. Sometimes it’s hard to know they even refer to⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe same story.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m3. People trying to achieve balance in reporting often relocate players onto the wrong team. For example,⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe Mueller report is not a “left wing” document and balance is not achieved by putting Mueller against a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mTrump surrogate.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m4. “Liberal” sources already include plenty of right wing opinions. For example, David Brooks and Ross⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mDouthat write for the New York Times. There’s no equivalent among the Wall St Journal columnists or Fox News⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhosts.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m5. News stories found only in right wing sources are usually mendacious. For example, reporting about the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mMichigan ballot glitch without mentioning that it was human error and corrected before reporting the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mresults.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mFundamentally, it’s not that we have differing information, it’s that we only accept information that⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mconfirms our world view. I can read dozens of articles written from the point of view that universal health⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcare will destroy the country and not one will ever resonate with me. It’s just too silly to me.⁣
  ⁣

   [1mcsnover[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mYes. Probably the worst thing about this election for me is that it seems to demonstrate conclusively that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m2016 was no aberration, no temporary mass hysteria, no failed experiment in electing a political outsider to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m“drain the swamp”. This distorted world view of us-vs-them tribalism seems to have totally consumed our⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpolitical system. Objective reality is dismissed by the majority of the population—most blatantly on the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mright, but also, increasingly, on the left. Even more shocking to me, highly regarded election data⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mscientists have twice now somehow been blinded to this, releasing poll after poll that fail to capture what⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mis actually happening in the minds of the electorate.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mCarl Sagan, in his 1995 book ‘The Demon-Haunted World’, wrote:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mI have a foreboding of an America in my children’s or grandchildren’s time — when the United States is a[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mservice and information economy; when nearly all the key manufacturing industries have slipped away to[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mother countries; when awesome technological powers are in the hands of a very few, and no one representing[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mthe public interest can even grasp the issues; when the people have lost the ability to set their own[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3magendas or knowledgeably question those in authority; when, clutching our crystals and nervously consulting[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mour horoscopes, our critical faculties in decline, unable to distinguish between what feels good and what’[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3ms true, we slide, almost without noticing, back into superstition and darkness.[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe moment he prophesied now appears to be upon us. I don’t know how we can restore this country to one where⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpeople mostly act in good faith and try to base decisions in science and fact. I see so many incredibly⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcompassionate people supporting the most despicable politicians. Right-wingers on Twitter repeating false⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtalking points that the left are trying to destroy the country while tweeting about how proud they are of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlocal youth offering free lawn care to disabled and senior citizens. Left-wingers openly insulting rural and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconservative people as the scum of the earth while relentlessly supporting policies intended to improve those⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msame peoples’ lives. How does this happen? What do we have to do—as individuals, as nations, as humans—to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mget it to stop?⁣

    [1mPeterisP[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mKilling the two party duopoly requires significant constitutional changes to how elections are held. One way⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto do that would be ranked choice voting as implemented in e.g. Maine⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m([34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranked-choice_voting_in_the_Un…[0m).⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHowever, the key point is that such a system would mainly benefit a potential third party, but any changes⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto the system need to be agreed upon by the current representatives whose interests and reelection would be⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhurt by such a change.⁣
  ⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mIn a "First past the post" electoral system, It's always more advantageous for the 3rd party to merge with⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe first or second party.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣

     [1mPeterisP[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe current system is game-theory-stable given the conditions of the USA structure of first-past-the-post.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mYou can look at the historical third parties in USA - a third party [3mcan[0m form and gain power (with great⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdifficulty) but then it pretty much immediately displaces one of the two parties, so you're back to a⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mtwo-party system just with different two parties.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mwolfhumble[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mFrom the perspective of a European outsider, I very much agree. A lot of problems seem to stem from the[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mtwo party system.[0m⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mI used to think the same way, but many (most?) countries in Europe end up having coalitions anyway, so you⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mend up really having just two blocks. More parties might give you the option to choose a party that is more⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mafter your taste, but in reality you (often) end up with coalitions that take most ideas from the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mstrongest party within the coalition.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI would assume the same thing would happen within the Democratic/Republican Party in the States as well,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mi.e. a compromise between the left/right wings within these parties based on what is shared by most⁣

   [1mzebrafish[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI honestly believe this is just a return to normal for both sides. Conservatism, before being injected with⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mneoliberalism by Thatcher and Reagan, has been about leaving other countries alone while focusing on⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mprotecting American interests. Speak softly and carry a big stick. Conservatives have never wanted US⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhegemony traditionally. Preservation of Bretton Woods has had to be a focus post-WWII in order to combat the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mspread of anti-American communism. Now that the Cold War has ended, conservatives have tried to find a way⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mback to focusing on American interests. It’s a delicate balance that has to be struck though. I think this is⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0malso the reason for the split in the Democratic Party. “Establishment” members are focused on preserving the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mneoliberal Bretton Woods status quo. The progressives are focused on doing away with the oligarchy that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msystem has created and moving towards a more socialistic global society.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI believe this is really just a return to the way things used to be, before the US decided to intervene in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mWWII and had to find a way to pay for the massive cost of that. Conservative and liberal are not opposites⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlike everybody thinks these days. Conservative and progressive are opposites. Liberal and authoritarian are⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mopposites. Both parties are (or should be) focused on the American ideal of liberalism and representative⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mgovernment chosen by the people while either preserving traditional values or advocating for enlightenment⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mvalues.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mHowever, real life is not that cut and dry, politics are messy, parties don’t fall exactly along these lines⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mand the media plays a part in dictating who should believe what. But in general I think Trump is an indicator⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat we’re headed for a more traditional alignment of values. Who knows, perhaps a viable third party will⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0memerge from this. A Conservative party, a progressive party, and a Bretton Woods establishment party.⁣

   [1mjoeevans1000[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mInterestingly, tech workers are responsible for such a resilient divide. Tech workers, the most numerous⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdemographic on this thread, are the ones coding up the bubbles or creating and maintaining their⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0minfrastructure.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe purpose of the bubbles is to keep you clicking or pressing. The purpose of that is to deliver ads or sell⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpremium services. If uncomfortable views are presented a user may click or press out of the service. Those⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0muncomfortable views are not to be confused with click bait allowed to drive bubble responses.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNo use blaming the architects or company leaders. If you are coding it up, maintaining the infrastructure, or⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mproviding auxiliary support to the bubble, you are responsible. The companies making the bubbles can't do it⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwithout you, and you are the one actually making it happen.⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mout of their country isn't compatible with the basic moral outlook of the 75-odd million people who voted⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0magainst him.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mTo take an extreme example, if a bunch of Nazis want to kill 10 million people, 'compromising' by agreeing to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlet them kill only 5 million people isn't acceptable — and yet, this is exactly the kind of moral compromise⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(truly in the other sense of the word) that would be involved in bringing together Trumpist and anti-Trumpist⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfactions.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIn addition to the moral divide, there is a reality/gullibility divide between the Trumpist and anti-Trumpist⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfactions. Trumpists believe an awful lot of stuff that is factually untrue. They reject global warming and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdismiss the scientific evidence as the product of a Chinese hoax to destroy America. 56% of Republicans now⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbelieve in Qanon (an ideological conspiracy theory born out of the argument that Democrats eat babies) to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msome extent[[37m0[0m]. The overwhelming majority of Trumpists get their news from Fox, a media outlet which spreads⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmore misleading information than accurate information.[[31m1[0m] How does anyone with a commitment to respecting⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconsensus reality reach people who have chosen to live in comforting fantasyland rather than cope with the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mworld as it is?⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI don't see any way for the US to get out of this mess without breaking up into multiple countries.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣

   [1mbleepblorp[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI realize this will sound snarky and/or overly aggressive. However, I'm being entirely serious and can't⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mquickly come up with a better way to phrase this:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣

  [1msoftwaredoug[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOn the data nerd side I continue to be shocked at how people misinterpret the certainty of polls/forecasts.
  [0mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data. Not infallible predictions
  [0mthe expected value will 100% happen.
  [0m
  [0mIt’s fairly revealing of society’s general innumeracy, just as it was 4 years ago when Trump won.

                                                   [1;2m▼ 75 replies[0m                                                 ⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mmetrics for the first time, but these are supposedly the most respective organizations in their field that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhave failed spectacularly for the second presidential election in a row. What value do they possibly serve?⁣

    [1mevgen[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI really have no idea where this idea that the polls failed comes from. There were only two bad calls this⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcycle and every other outcome was within the margin of error. It was pretty much the same case in 2016 where⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpeople who had no idea what they were talking about suddenly decided they were certain polling failed⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbecause they are unable to grasp the concept of margin of error and sample size.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPolls can only guess about turnout and the try to work backwards from there. The turnout estimates were⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwrong but not shockingly so, and as a consequence a lot of polls ended up having the result be at the far⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mend of their margin of error. Nothing went wrong. Polling is hard. Get over this idea that you can have some⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msort of certainty regarding an election until we actually hold the election.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mKZeillmann[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mMy issue with polling is that many races were well beyond the margin of error. The Senate polling in⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mparticular was bad this year.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mSara Gideon was favored to win the Maine race in the polling, because there hadn't been a single poll⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mshowing Collins in the lead since July. She lost her race by 9 points.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIt's also strange to see the region makes a difference in the poll error. The polls in Minnesota were⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mbasically spot-on, but in Wisconsin (demographically very similar), the polling average was Biden +8, with⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mone ABC news poll showing him +17, the kind of outlier result you'd expect with a +8 average. He's gonna⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwin there by ~1 percentage point.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThere's something wrong with how a lot of these pollsters determine samples, or how they judge someone's⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mlikeliness to vote.⁣

  ⁣
     [1mtitzer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mSlapping +/- 5% on top of a prediction that is systematically off by ~5% isn't "in the margin of error",⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mit's just simply [3moff[0m. For one prediction, two predictions, no problem. They fall somewhere in this range⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwith probability distribution (usually a Bell curve around the mean). But for hundreds, if not thousands,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mof polls to be so [3msystematically[0m off, it is not "within the margin of error" or a statistical fluke. If it⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwas, you would expect a normal distribution around the mean of the polls. The mean was completely off.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mPut simply, it was sampling bias. Pollsters screwed up. They either sampled the wrong voters, the wrong⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mareas, mispredicted who would turn out, or voters did not accurately report who they planned to vote for.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mGarbage in, garbage out.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mYou can try to correct for sampling bias, but if you are blind to it, as your comment pushes more people to⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mbe, then you will fail.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mjs2[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI know they were within the margin of error, but the polls were all systematically within the margin of⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0merror in the same direction. Did a single poll that was wrong predict at GOP win and end up a Democratic⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwin?⁣
  ⁣
     [1mqppo[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mOne could argue the strategic mistakes of the Clinton campaign (ignoring the rust belt) and near fatal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmistakes of the Biden campaign (which looks to be on issues swinging voters in battleground states) were⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdriven by bad polling.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mWhen I hear the conversation about "the polls were wrong" it's never been "the predictions were outside the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0merror margin" so much as "voter sentiment was not accurately measured in regions where voters were most⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mlikely to flip and why they would do so."⁣
  ⁣

    [1mdrdec[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe campaigns do not rely on the publicly available poll data for the reasons you pointed out - they need⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maccurate polling in order to make serious decisions about resources. They pay polling companies to get⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maccurate polls and they keep this data private.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe publicly available polls are done for free by polling companies or by news organizations. Unfortunately⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msome of these companies apparently have an agenda to push. So they skew their sample away from what the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mlikely voters are to get the result they want for propaganda purposes.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI think that the rise of Nate Silver has ironically made this situation worse. He advocates taking an⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maverage of polls to get a true view of the situation. So if you are skewing you poll to get a certain⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0moutcome and you know the poll will be averaged, you need to warp your results even further.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mOk, disclaimer time - I don't have any inside knowledge or real evidence of any of the above. It does seem⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto fit however. I can't explain why it seems all the distorting is to make the Dems lead seem bigger than it⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mis - that is, why aren't there pollers on the other side of the aisle doing the same thing?⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mSo you'll have to decide for yourself if there is any merit to the above theory.⁣

    [1mpessimizer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPolls are astrological race science, and the reason you'll never be able to convince anyone of this is⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0madequately covered by the book [3mWhen Prophecy Fails[0m. I've come to think that their bias is only slightly⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mideological, but instead springs more from a self-serving impulse to mirror the current beliefs of the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maudience most likely to believe in polls i.e. people overly impressed by credentials. They enjoy the sheer⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mvolume of numbers, rather than their actual usefulness.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAlternate phrasings of identical questions asked in polls creates differences in outcome vastly larger than⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe effects they claim to detect. Somehow Nate Silver managed to get rich by selling synthetic CDOs of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0marbitrary polls (to people with his identical political outlook.)⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe only real poll is to ask the same questions, in the same way, as the ballot sheet does. Ideally these⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mshould be asked as people are entering or leaving the voting booth, and people should be paid for their⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mresponses, in order not to bias yourself towards bored loudmouths with nothing to do. This would be good for⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maccuracy, not for usefulness in anything but generating a suspicion of election fraud.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mInstead, they're trying to figure out what percentage of black people go to the polls in Missouri, and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpretending that the self-selected black voter has more in common politically with the general black phone⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0manswerer than the Missouri voter. Relying on that arbitrary assumption is the entire basis of their field.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0medit: I haven't read [34msite.pennpress.org/aha-2021/9780812250046/race-and-t…[0m yet, but I heard an interview⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwith the author around the time that it came out, and it's another hidden history of a field that has⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcompletely unearned legitimacy. "Political Science" might largely be considered an outgrowth of scientific⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mracism.⁣

   [1mwill4274[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI'm on the nerd side too, but I was quite surprised. Sampling isn't the only source of error in election⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpolling - people also change their minds. In this election, people decided who they were going to vote for⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhistorically early - the lowest portion of people in the history of exit polls indicated they decided in the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mweek before the election. In theory, this effect should reduce the width of the probability distribution, and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0myet, the polls were off again, in the same direction as they are always off, by a little bit more than⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0maverage.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mA little scrutiny here is worthwhile. In 2016, for example, the polls were off in part because pollsters⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mweighted the black demographic in proportion to their voting behavior in 2008 and 2012 (when a black⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcandidate was running, boosting turnout). The actual 2016 black turnout looked more similar to 2004 or 2000 -⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mother elections where a black candidate wasn't running. Though I haven't dived into the 2020 polling data,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mit wouldn't surprise me if a similar effect were at play.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIt's also become noticeable harder to do polling. Once upon a time, everybody had a landline, so random⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdialing worked really well. Now, some people have more phones than others, and people are increasingly less⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwilling to talk to pollsters, increasing the error rate.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThese are all important things to talk about - when you dismiss it as "oh yeah, polls are never perfect," you⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mprematurely shut down the conversation. Don't let perfect be the enemy of the good. The polls could be better⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mand it's important to talk about how.⁣
  ⁣
    [1msaalweachter[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThere is also "what polls directly measure" and "what we infer from them".⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mBesides the usual adjustments for likely voter models, we also do things like infer how people will vote in⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHouse and Senate elections based on Presidential polling, because we do a lot more Presidential polling than⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdown ballot, because money.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mSo one early thing that seems to have happened this year (and again, we are still early in the process to be⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmaking final verdicts in "what happened" retrospectives) is that people split their ballot more than⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0manticipated, which means that the inferences we were making about down ballot races based on Presidential⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mperformance were off.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mSo not quite a polling error, but an example of uncertainty that may not have been correctly taken into⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maccount in forecasting.⁣
  ⁣

   [1mtsimionescu[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mYou're picking the easiest number to misread - the overall "chance of being elected", which doesn't really⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmean anything.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mMuch more interesting are the direct results predictions, especially per state where they matter most. Those⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mare polls that give a particular result with a +- confidence interval. If the polls were to any extent⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcompetently done, you expect the result to be well within that margin of error.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe reality though has been that the results have been well outside the margin of error, sometimes multiple⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msigmas from the actual result - that is simply unacceptable for a poll. The only conclusion should be that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpolling data can be completely ignored, as it doesn't seem to have any clear relationship with the final⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mresults.⁣

    [1mevgen[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIndividual polls were sometimes outside the margin, but collectively the polls were not far off the mark and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcollectively they were within the margin of error. This is why sites like 538 were able to model the various⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0moutcomes with some degree of certainty and ONCE AGAIN manage to get results within the range of expected⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mprobabilities. You really seem to have a hard time understanding both polling and probability and in⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mparticular the relationship between sample size and error. I suggest a bit more research.⁣

   [1mphlakaton[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI think it's more fundamental than numeracy. If the polls suggest there is a ⅔ probability you are going to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwin an election, but you lose, does that mean the polls were wrong? What if the probability was 9/10?⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI think the problem is trying to make sense of outliers and uncertainty, and that, in an election with 150M+⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mvariables, you will end up with a result that isn't quite what anyone predicted. In other words: it's not⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mnumeracy, it's epistemology.⁣
  ⁣
    [1msrtjstjsj[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mFivethirtyeight's polling averaging model underestimated Trump in [3mall[0m the swing states. Trump wine 2-3⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mstates predicted for Biden, and 0 vice versa. States that Biden had a supposedly strong lead in turned out⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto be statistical ties in the official vote. The direction bias in the polls (about 20 of 25) is obvious,⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mit's not symmetric random error.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mTheCoelacanth[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mModeling correlated polling errors is basically what 538's models are all about. They model how far off the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpolls could end up being from the actual result based on past elections.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe polls are never 100% accurate. The pollsters have to estimate how many of each type of voter will⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mactually show up to vote and what the response rate for each type of voter was. It is not an exact science.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mphlakaton[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mTo which you then have to ask: 1) were the discrepancies within the margin of error? and 2) to what extent⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mare you justified in critiquing the polls based on a sample size of one?⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI understand that the voting percentage we saw nationally was within the margin of error that 538⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpredicted, and that the specific configuration of electoral votes we saw was also one of the outcomes⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mconsidered by the models.⁣
  ⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0muncertainty is epistemological; it’s not describing a stochastic process.⁣

   [1mwesnerm2[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mTo be fair, we still don't know the loss of votes through mail-in voting. Mail-in voting is more convenient⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwhich would likely increase participation, but missing signatures, naked ballots, late or undelivered mail,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0metc can prevent those ballots from being counted.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mWhen there is a major difference in voting patterns between the two political parties, then polls may not⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mactually be inaccurate. In this case, Democrats chose mail-in voting and Republicans, by and large, chose⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0min-person after being directed by the president.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAlso, some percentage of mail-in ballots may not have reached their destination because of possible election⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0minterference through reduced post office efficiency—in particular, fewer mail sorting machines, lower hours,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdeprioritized mails, etc.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIn short, the polls don't take into account election interference in the post office or unsuccessful⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdelivery. If most people from both parties were voting in-person, maybe we might have had more parity between⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe polls and election results.⁣

   [1mbendmorris[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data.[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThey would give you a probability distribution if they were truly random samples. But in reality, response⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrates are very low, and pollsters make up for this using demographic weighting and modeling - so the results⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdon't actually represent any real population, but rather are extrapolated from people who respond onto a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhypothetical population that the pollster thinks is likely to vote. This is why they are spectacularly and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msystematically off, more and more over time. It's not just variance.⁣
  ⁣
   [1meinpoklum[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data.[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m… and a lot of assumptions about the supposed underlying probability spaces.⁣
  ⁣
   [1mmeroes[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mYou could also fit the same data with "people polled thought they could vote until their vote was⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpreferentially suppressed". So the polls will never match outcomes. And that it happened in the same⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdirection two cycles in a row leads credence.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(I do not know why the forecasts are wrong, but I don't see why Parent is at all justified in his statement).⁣
  ⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mYour premise is wrong. Twitter's actions weren't as a result of something it disagreed with. Your⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcomment/thought illustrates one of the REAL root problems … and that is we are living in a state of two⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mapparent states of "factual reality". Unfortunately this is not possible. There is only one set of facts.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mUntil we can return to that, we will be repeating similar scenarios.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mauthoritative voice is determining what's true and what's not. You're shifting the burden of truth from one⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msource to the other until there is no one you can trust.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mStatement: Foo is Bar. [[31m1[0m]⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mBy asking "Who gets to decide the truth", you're essentially saying "Why should I trust anyone?" and by⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0melse's facts A, B, and C. I have family members and friends who live in seemingly totally alternate⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0muniverses, dominated by [3mwhat I see as[0m conspiracy theories, pseudoscience, and a cultural persecution⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcomplex. But as [3mthey[0m describe it: it's I who live in a media-manufactured alternate reality characterized by⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mWhat everyone is missing is: both universes might as well be correct, to the observer. It's like measuring⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwhat speed someone is going in two different relativistic frames of reference. You can both be right and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcome up with different numbers. It's a tough problem to solve. We can't solve it by just pointing at the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mout-groups and saying "ha-ha how stupid are they for believing in rubbish!" They are just not going to be⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mconvinced by someone who believe a totally different set of facts.⁣

    [1mhectormalot[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mWant to ban group X which is fighting with group Y in a tit-for-tat skirmish over decades? How do you[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mdecide who is right? How do you decide truth?[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI think there is a difference between ‘right vs wrong’ and ‘factually correct vs incorrect’.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPlatforms like Twitter will rarely be in a position to decide right/wrong, because in many opposed⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdiscussion both sides will use the platform.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mOn the factual correctness, platforms can more easily take a stance in high impact cases. I would assume⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthat they’d have out the same warnings on Biden’s Twitter if he had said ‘I won’ on Tuesday.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThat leaves a challenge: how do you decide what’s a fact? For example on the vote count. Most outlets say⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe reported figures are fact, but it implies trusting the process of counting and reporting. Removing that⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mimplied trust means others can take ‘there is fraud!’ as fact just as well.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mTwitter seems to use the mainstream media (eg AP predicting the election outcome) as a base of trust (and so⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdo I). But I’ve come to realize that once you don’t trust the media, it is easy to believe in another set of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfacts (that are true for you), and suddenly (to you) it seems Twitter is censoring.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI hope people will find and trust each other again.⁣

     [1mTuringNYC[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mThat leaves a challenge: how do you decide what’s a fact? For example on the vote count. Most outlets say[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mthe reported figures are fact, but it implies trusting the process of counting and reporting. Removing[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mthat implied trust means others can take ‘there is fraud!’ as fact just as well.[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mTwitter seems to use the mainstream media (eg AP predicting the election outcome) as a base of trust (and[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mso do I). But I’ve come to realize that once you don’t trust the media, it is easy to believe in another[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mset of facts (that are true for you), and suddenly (to you) it seems Twitter is censoring.[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI'm glad you brought up the case of the election. It is a harder question for social media to arbitrate⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcentrally. For example, "There is Fraud" could be true or false, and certainly [3msomewhere you'll find fraud[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmaking the statement both true in fact and false in spirit. Then, there is the dark matter of [3meverything[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[3mthe newspaper doesnt even cover[0m — US newspapers only regularly cover US news, allies, key areas of the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mworld, and major events. Imagine a dairy-farmer trade war between two asian nations — unlikely to be⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcovered, so what is the truth? For that matter, imagine the civil rights of small minorities in the US —⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdepending on the minority group, unlikely to be covered even by major us newspapers.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mLet me give you a harder example now. Anything to do spanning two sovereign nations, especially one⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0minvolving war, civilian casualties, or war crimes. Pick your example: Russia/Ukraine, China/Taiwan,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIndia/Pakistan, Yemen/Saudi Arabia. Both sides will have their national own newspapers which will support⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mtheir own country. Which side does Twitter take?⁣

     [1mskuhn[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mFreedom of speech must have limits.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe classic analogy is that a person shouldn't be allowed to shout "FIRE" and thereby cause panic in a⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcrowded theater, when there is no such fire. The right of the one person to (falsely) speak is outweighed⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mby the right of the many people present to their own safety.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mTrump saying "I WON THIS ELECTION, BY A LOT!" [[31m1[0m] is clearly equivalent to shouting "FIRE". He has not won⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe election, he does not have more popular votes or more electoral college votes, and he has presented no⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mproof or substantive argument to contradict this narrative.⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0min a crowded theater on the internet.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNot only is it Twitter's prerogative to act accordingly, I'd go further and say it is their ethical duty.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAnd yes, if Biden did the equivalent "from the other side", Twitter would act in exactly the same way.⁣
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

  [0m[31m▎[0mwhat long-established practice.⁣

  [1mrandomsearch[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0m[This has been hinted at in various threads but I'm stating it clearly here]
  [0m
  [0mA fundamental cause of political polarisation is social media. Tech platforms incentivised by advertising to
  [0mincrease engagement have (probably mostly inadvertently) become manipulation engines that have destabilised
  [0mdemocracies.
  [0m
  [0mI think at this moment in time the tech community should take pause to consider what we have done. We started
  [0mwith heady ideals and hopes, especially for the internet, but we have veered a long way from that vision.
  [0m
  [0mAs engineers, we have great power in this world. For the foreseeable future, our skills will be highly in
  [0mdemand and shape the future of humanity, in every area of society - from finance to health, from entertainment
  [0mto politics.
  [0m
  [0mIf you work for a social media company, or a search engine, or any company that is reliant on adtech or high
  [0mengagement for its income, then I implore you to think long and hard about how your actions may have
  [0mcontributed to bringing us to this point, and whether it is possible to change the course of your organisation
  [0mor it would be better to leave.
  [0m
  [0mMore positively, the large social media networks are now entrenched corporations, and they have lost the
  [0madvantages that startups confer. With sufficient imagination and hard work there are many opportunities to
  [0mdisrupt those companies with the compelling mission of making the world a better, not a worse, place.

                                                   [1m▶ 4 replies[0m                                                  ‌
                                                   [1;2m▼ 4 replies[0m                                                  ⁣

   [1mehsankia[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI absolutely agree this is an issue, but I honestly think it even transcends social media algorithms. Well,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfor one thing, the news media is just as much to blame, pushing clickbait and stories that induce the most⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrage. The next step is, regardless of social media sites, people tend to share said stories far more, so it's⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0ma vicious circle. I think any large connected social media site, regardless of the algorithms, will lead to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0ma similar result.⁣
  ⁣
   [1mThorncorona[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mHint: 'Personalized' algorithms simply mean tailored to one's biases. As in Google will show liberals only⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mliberal articles, and conservatives conservative articles.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mrandomsearch[0m [35mPP [0m[2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI think there's an important distinction between recommendation algorithms, which is how I'd describe what⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0myou're referring to, and _algorithms designed to maximise engagement_.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mRecommendation algorithms try to provide content that you'll enjoy, like new movies to watch.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mEngagement algorithms will try to find content that keeps you engaged, even if that means enraging you. They⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdon't just exploit biases, rather they exploit what triggers you.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mMahn[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mAnd therein lies the problem, algorithms can't tell if you click and spend time with something because you⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0menjoy it, or because it enraged you.⁣
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

   [1mFooBarBizBazz[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mYeah, there's a lot of really dumb straw-manning going on.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mA good phrase I ran into is "strategic empathy". Like Sun Tzu teaches:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m"If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0myourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0menemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle."⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSadly, humans seem allergic to this kind of thinking. As Orwell writes in "Notes on Nationalism":⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m"The nationalist does not go on the principle of simply ganging up with the strongest side. On the contrary,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhaving picked his side, he persuades himself that it is the strongest, and is able to stick to his belief⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0meven when the facts are overwhelmingly against him. Nationalism is power hunger tempered by self-deception.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEvery nationalist is capable of the most flagrant dishonesty, but he is also – since he is conscious of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mserving something bigger than himself – unshakeably certain of being in the right."⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe smart (if mistaken) reasons to vote Trump were always trade and the Democratic Party's abandonment of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mLabor.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAnd Republicans, on the other hand, who think Biden is a socialist are delusional.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIt's possible, though, that people aren't as dumb as they seem. For an individual, pretending not to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mempathize with the opposition is probably safer in a tribalized society. So perhaps that's what we're really⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwitnessing.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mJoeri[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThanks for the mention of Orwell’s notes on nationalism. I just read it and it is remarkably relevant, even⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mif the movements used as examples aren’t.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAs a European it was incomprehensible to me why anyone would vote for trump as I had only received the straw⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mman version of Trump through my local media. But when traveling the U.S. early 2016 I had the good fortune⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mof spending a few hours on a bus with two trump voters and having them explain their hopes for a trump⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpresidency, and it no longer seemed irrational. The hope that having no loyalties or obligations to the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpolitical powers that be he could actually have policies which benefited regular people seemed reasonable.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThere is a fair argument to be made his actual economic policies have indeed mostly benefited Americans, so⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msomeone voting just based on the economy would not be irrational in choosing Trump.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mStill, he’s Donald Trump, and a bully. I don’t think I could ever be convinced to ignore all the other stuff⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto the degree of voting for him. I can understand those who outright dismiss him and anyone aligned with him⁣

     [1mdefen[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThey haven't been, in the long view. Historically abortion was a Catholic issue, and sometimes liberal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mProtestant[[31m1[0m]. It generally wasn't an issue for Evangelicals, who were also mainly on the political left.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThen in the late 60s the teenage son of a popular Evangelical pastor/author[[33m2[0m] became concerned for the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mrights of the unborn, convinced his father to take that message to the masses, it worked, and Republicans⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mfigured out that it would be a way to build a new coalition.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIf you look at the extreme countercultures of the 60s, you see one side who hated "the system" that⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mproduced mass affluence, but loved the fruits of it. The other side loved the system, but hated the fruits.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mSo one way to look at it is as a sort of political shibboleth indicating that you were definitely on one⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mside and not the other.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[[31m1[0m] [34mbooks.google.com/books?id=cf5RFWIMJugC&pg=PA42&lpg=P…[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[[33m2[0m] [34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Schaeffer[0m⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mNoted:⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mOf course, these two explanations are not mutually exclusive. Both may have some validity. Moreover, as[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mMichael Tesler has argued, economic anxiety and discontent among white voters in 2016 appear to be[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mclosely connected to racial resentment. His analysis of survey data indicate that many white voters,[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mespecially those without college degrees, believe that racial minorities and immigrants have been favored[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mby government policies while their own communities have been neglected, especially during the Obama[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3myears (Tesler 2016b). The Trump campaign explicitly connected these issues by arguing that illegal[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mimmigrants were taking jobs away from American citizens and reducing wages for American workers.[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mTo sort out these competing explanations, we test the hypothesis that Trump’s surge among white working[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mclass voters, compared with previous GOP presidential candidates, was due to his explicit appeal to white[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mracial resentment and ethno-nationalism. Thus, Trump’s campaign may have helped to politicize these[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mattitudes, identifying them with a political party, especially among less educated white voters who tend[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mto be less attentive to political campaigns and therefore less aware of differences between candidates on[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mracial and other issues (Tesler 2016c). To test this hypothesis, we can compare the correlations between[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mscores on the racial resentment scale and relative ratings of the Republican and Democratic presidential[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mcandidates on the feeling thermometer scale over time among white voters with and without college[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mdegrees.[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m* [34mdoi.org/10.1177%2F0002716218811309[0m⁣

    [1mrm445[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mA couple of ideas: (1) Centrism is situational. One might think that the status quo is objectively⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mreasonably close to the ideal, in terms of the general way society is arranged even if there are many⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mimperfections. (2) Centrism is technocratic. If you don't favour a lurch to the left or right, it would make⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msense to want efficient improvements to how things are run - accepting good ideas regardless of which area⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mof the political compass they come from, bipartisan support for policies on their merits.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mBased on the above, centrism (and indeed, being centre-left or centre-right) seems viable as a real belief⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthat people can hold, not some strategy to appear above it all for social benefit, or as a stratagem used by⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msomeone actually highly partisan. A centrist's goals could be directly met by encouraging trial of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdifferent ideas across the political spectrum, and consistent meta-level rules rather than tribalist⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthinking. Trying to rise above the bunfighting isn't the benefit of centrist views, it's a necessity to⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0menable the things they want to achieve.⁣

  [0mIt should be made easier to prosecute a president for illegal activity.
  [0m
  [0mThings like showing tax returns should be formalized.
  [0m
  [0mNew regulation needs to be put in place to limit the spread of falsehoods and conspiracy theories over facts.
  [0m
  [0mSocial media currently benefit economically from this and that has to stop. The economic incentive to spread
  [0mcrazy and extremist ideas has to be removed.

   [1mkortilla[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mIt should be made easier to prosecute a president for illegal activity.[0m⁣
