  [1mChuckMcM[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOne of the things this election, and the last four years, has shown me, is the impact of technology on our
  [0mpolitical discourse. It hasn't been a "good" insight.
  [0m
  [0mFederal Election records indicate that the leadership of technology companies overwhelmingly supported a set
  [0mof values that their employees appear to just as overwhelmingly reject. That dissonance is really quite
  [0mremarkable.
  [0m
  [0mI see one of the fundamental challenges facing the new administration is how to address this. I am not a fan
  [0mof government regulation, more of a "let the markets decide" kind of guy. I recognize however there is a
  [0msystemic risk where the technology "owner" can exploit it to harm society in a way that was previously
  [0mimpossible.
  [0m
  [0mWhile the country has focused on disinformation and hate speech, consider a company that controls, in real
  [0mtime, the self-driving software in a car. Such a technology, if weaponized, to could kill hundreds of
  [0mthousands of people. Or it could be weaponize to kill select people who were in the intersection of riding in
  [0ma self-driven car and in disfavor by the company that really controls that car.
  [0m
  [0mEarly on in my career I chose not to work for military contractors who were the "big" employers in Los Angeles
  [0mat the time I graduated from college. They were clearly engaged in finding clever, or at least more effective,
  [0mways to kill people and that wasn't where I wanted to spend my time. But what about someone working on self
  [0mdriving? It saves lives by avoiding some of the things end up resulting in crashes. But it also provides an
  [0mopportunity for great evil.
  [0m
  [0mDo we trust the person in charge to not be evil? Companies change and while they might declare their
  [0mintentions when they are growing, what happens when they are on top? Sometimes those quaint notions get cast
  [0maside when being a little bit evil makes what you're trying to do that much easier or maybe that much more
  [0mprofitable.
  [0m
  [0mWhat is the appropriate response, in a democracy, to a small number of people controlling a potential weapon
  [0mthat can destroy that democracy? Sadly this is no longer an idle question.
  [0m
  [0mI don't have any answers here, just more questions.

   [0m[33m▎[0mpacket, or a text message to the car. That person would be in a position to tell the car to ignore its⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mhappen?"⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe change here is cars that are always connected to the Internet and have command authority over all of the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msystems in the car. Before if you wanted to alter the software controlling a car you took it to a dealer, or⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0ma mod-shop, but now it just shows up in your car. What sort of insider threat programs does Tesla have?⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mWhat sort of controls are their on releases? Do third parties have any opportunity to audit everything in⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe code? What happens if Elon orders an employee to put some code in? Do they do it? Do they report it?⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAnd not to pick on Tesla here, the same goes for GM/Cruise and Waymo right? ALL self driving systems that⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mare currently in development have full control of the car, an always connected component, and a dynamic⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msoftware update capability. Should it be required they also have a mechanical switch that forces manual⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcontrol without any means of circumventing the switch in software? That would have to come as a government⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mregulation right? And then what happens when someone steals the Waymo van by throwing the switch and driving⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maway with it?⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mHopefully that gives you a sense of where my head is here in these questions.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mConsider Facebook, which is a popular bad guy here[[31m1[0m]. There have been "crank" bulletin board systems since⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe 70's at least, and before that with HAM radio operators riling each other up over various perceived⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mslights and insults. In 2016 we got to see that with a precision advertisement targeting system, and way⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmore insights into people than ever existed before, companies like Cambridge Analytica could precisely⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtarget individuals who were susceptible to a particular line of reasoning. CA essentially offered⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mRadicalization As a Service. We are still dealing with that to this day. Was there any reason to worry about⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mBBS software? Not when it was a self selecting group. But when the BBS became a billion BBSes all hosted on⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe same platform with clear insights into the demographics, fears, and hopes of all of those BBSes at⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0monce, that was something new. And it changed the risk profile and was weaponized against people.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIt has always been desirable for groups to find somewhat like minded people in order to form a group for⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcollective action. That is the 'demand' side of the question, but before Facebook it wasn't economic to do⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthat at scale. With Facebook it did become economic to do that, and it gave anyone a new capability. Not all⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mof those people have (or had) people's best interest at heart and so we get the bad as well as the good.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPrior to self driving cars with over the air updates, continuous network connectivity, and full access to⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mall systems on a car, has their been the capability (actualized or not) for someone anywhere in the world to⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtarget a specific car and take control away from the driver. The previous poster child, for vehicles⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0manyway, were cars with computers that controlled things like engine starting/stopping and brakes. One issue⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwas that you had to be near the car to know which one you wanted to attack. Self driving cars finesse that⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mby giving you an interior camera view. It is a different realm of problem.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[[31m1[0m] I don't consider Facebook a bad actor per se, I believe that the forces that motivate them (page⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mengagement, ad clicks, ad sales, etc) find ways to be serviced. And those ways are not constrained by⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0methics.⁣
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

   [1mtptacek[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe big difference is that 2000 revolved around a disputed recount, in a race with a margin of fewer than⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m1000 votes. There will be recounts in this race, but:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(1) There's no reason to believe they'll change the outcome much (recounts in 2016 didn't) --- states have⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlearned since 2000 and have moved away from faulty ballot designs.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(2) The recounts will be occurring in multiple states, and Trump needs to sweep them.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(3) The margins in those recounts are much bigger than in 2000 --- tens of thousands of votes, not hundreds.⁣
  ⁣
   [1mjcranmer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe biggest factor in Florida is that the ballot marking system that Florida used at that time was extremely⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mprone to failure, especially with regards to machine reading of ballots (which itself could cause an apparent⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmark on the ballot!). This means that trying to divine whether or not a ballot recorded an intent to vote⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfor a candidate can be subjective and depends on the exact standard you want to use, which Florida didn't⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mspecify (and the Florida Supreme Court ruled was ultimately too vague).⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSince 2000, most states have switched to optical scan ballots as their paper records. These ballots have much⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlower error rates, closer to 1 error per million votes. I don't think there's been a single race using⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0moptical scan ballots where a recount actually caused a winner to switch.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mdlp211[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAnother thing that complicated this was that the way you punched the ballot resulted in the chad going into⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0ma waste bin. Those waste bins would fill up to the point where it would physically prevent you from being⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mable to punch out your chad.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThat election and SCOTUS ruling was a mess, and as a consequence did a lot of damage to this countries⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0minstitutions.⁣
  ⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mIt's more nuanced than that. Gore wanted some select counties recounted, bush wanted no counties recounted,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbut if there was going to be a rexound then bush wanted the whole state recounted. In the end the SCbrules⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat the 14th amendment said that including votes with "hanging Chad's" and other clear intent required the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwhole state to be recounted. Gore conceeded because there wasn't enough time and he believed that a whole⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mstate recount wouldn't have favored him in the end. History reflects that it may have been a bad strategy for⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mGore to try and recount just some counties because he may well have won if he argued for a state wide⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrecount from the beginning.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0min the 19th and early 20th century, culminating in the First and Second World Wars. For all the negatives⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mof what the US has done with its military since then, they're not a hundredth as bad as what went on before⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mby any objective measure.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe [3mPax Americana[0m has been good for stability and with stability comes prosperity. If the United States⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mtruly gave up its hegemony and turned isolationist, you'd see a resurgence of rearmament and jockeying for⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpower among nations, inevitably followed by a new era of war after war.⁣

    [1mcknoxrun[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI agree it has demonstrated resilience, a positive thing indeed. But I think it's good to consider what⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwould happen in other countries should a character like Trump be elected. In Canada, a polarizing character⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mlike Trump would be exceedingly unlikely to form a majority government. As a minority government, they would⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbe subject to "no-confidence" votes regularly. When a government passes a budget for example, if the budget⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdoes not pass the house, the government automatically crumbles and an election is called. Additionally, as⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe prime minister is simply the head of the party, his vote carries no more weight than other members, and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhe can be fired by his own party at any time.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mA lot of checks and balances are baked into a multi-party system. One inherent advantage is less⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpolarization, as there are more parties to represent the various views of the people. However, there are of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcourse a lot of improvements that could be made to the Canadian governance system (ditching first past the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpost for example), but I do believe this style of government is more resilient than the US system.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAt the same time, our government has not, and will likely not, be put to the test by someone like Trump. It⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mis commendable that the US system has withstood what many feared could be the start of the downfall of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mdemocracy in the US.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mcome away with the honest impression that there really was a stolen election. Since democracy hinges on⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[3mthe losing side[0m accepting that loss, action that undermine that are quite problematic.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mPresident Trump's action so far, both before the election and after, are entirely in line with the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0maccusations against him; in essence: he's willing to undermine democracy to try and hold on to power.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mtry and steal the election. And if he had been backed in that (which isn't entirely impossible, because⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msome of the toss-up states have republican-appointed courts, republican legislatures, and republican⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mgovernors, and of course the heavily tilted supreme court now), [3mthen[0m things would have gotten dicey. In⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthat situation, just like in other strong-man democracies, the outcome of the election would have been⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mrigged. Would democrats have backed down? Or would they have disputed the elections, even though formally⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthey lost them? That's the kind of thing that breaks a democracy; because both backing down and⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mconfrontation are terrible outcomes.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mTo their credit - because that's how it's supposed to work in a democracy - those toss-up states did not⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mseriously try to steal votes (although the vote-segregation thing is pretty close). And of course we don't⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[3mknow[0m Trump would really have stolen the election, given the opportunity, since it never arose. But we can⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msee that he took all possible steps in that direction at least; and that's something the US needs to deal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwith in the future for the sake of stability. It ended well this time; it might not every time.⁣

     [1mhilbert42[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIn 2016 I put the result down to the general disenchantment in many democratic countries with democracy⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mgenerally - similar to the 'logic' behind brexit.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThat I can understand but it's the relative closeness of the vote in this election that surprised me.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mEarlier I was looking at a live online polling update with maps of both state and popular vote figures. The⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpopular vote map was detailed enough for me to drill down to county level and finer. In states like Ohio, N⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mDakota and Nebraska with sparce populations and high overall Republican vote one would occasionally (but⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mnot infrequently) come across small settlements of 500/1000 or so only 20/50 miles apart where the vote in⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mone was say D-70%, R-28%, Lib-2% and the other almost exactly the opposite with Lib remaining the same at⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mabout 2%.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThis seems to backup your tribal identity point very well. Given that these settlements likely have only⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mtrees or farmland between them the figures are actually quite startling. I took into account that some may⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mhave been Native American reservations (which I've not yet ruled out), so I resampled in other states with⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mlow populations such as Vermont and New Hampshire and found similar instances (of course, with these latter⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0minstances the overall state figures had the Democrats in the majority).⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThese demographics are fascinating to say the least and I'm going to revisit them again shortly.⁣

    [1mmitchdoogle[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI don't see how anyone can argue for the electoral college as a feature in our modern times. Our Senate and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mthe electoral college were designed in order to get support from colonies to form the new USA. It worked⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwell for that purpose.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mWe have entirely different goals now. We should be aiming for fair elections in which one person's vote is⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mequal to any other's regardless of the state they reside. The electoral college is downright repulsive once⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0myou realize how unfairly it treats citizens in more populated states compared to those in less populated⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mstates.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe electoral college now has the potential of pulling the union apart. If California and New York see a few⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmore elections in which their citizens' votes are discounted, resulting in popular vote winners losing the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpresidency, then it would be logical for them to secede. They can take their massive economies and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0maccompanying tax dollars and leave this system behind, as it should've been a long time ago.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mRemoving electoral college would remove all the interesting stuff about campaigning. Campaigns would focus⁣

     [1mthrowaway201103[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe constitution declares that the president is elected by the states, not by the people directly. The⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0melectoral college serves to moderate the influence of dense population areas.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mOn a straight popular vote basis, the large urban centers in a handful of states would select the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpresident. Their interests and motivations will necessarily be different from rural areas.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe electoral college gives populous states proportionally more influence, as they have more congressional⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mrepresentatives and thus more electoral votes. But it serves to balance that against the interests of less⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpopulated states, which are also part of the country and should not be considered completely irrelevant in⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe process.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mthrowawaysea[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe reality of the power balance the opposite of what you’re saying, in my opinion. Places like CA and NY⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mhave incredible influence and power even with the electoral college. The calls for one person’s vote being⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mequal to others nationally is just a virtuous rhetorical argument to justify a power grab that would take⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mpower away from places which already have diminished influence.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe reality is that different locations have different ways of life and culture and politics, and therefore⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mself determination must be supported through some mechanisms (like the electoral college) for a federal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0munion to make sense and for those peoples to feel represented. If we are undoing that we need to also give⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mThe senate system of 2 senators per state and the electoral college are fantastic features to provide[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mcompromise. If we just used popular vote for choosing the president, they're more likely to be the same⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mparty as the one controlling the House.⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mNot exactly true. In every trial in the senate, the guilty votes come exclusively from one side, but the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mnot guilty votes are historically slightly more bipartisan. For both Clinton and Johnson, all the guilty⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mvotes came from republicans, while all senate democrats and a handful of republicans voted not guilty.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mTrump's impeachment trial was unique in that it was a straight party line vote. Nixon almost certainly⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwould have been impeached (the Democrats had a large majority in the house), and a large number of⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mbecause it was expected to be a mathematical improbability of a Republican win in that state. Whenever a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mstate gets called (and inevitably therefore the presidency), it is done because the math nerds at the media⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0morganizations put the odds of the other party winning outside the realm of what can realistically be achieved⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0min the opinion of the analysts. There is no legal requirement to be eventually correct in your calls.⁣
  ⁣

   [1motterley[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mHistory has shown that recounts rarely change anything beyond a few hundredths of a percent, if that (see:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mFlorida 2000). The margins are wide enough, and there are enough states that tipped blue, that it is⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mextremely unlikely as a matter of pure mathematics that there would be any change in outcome — even if⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mTrump's fans were granted every legal challenge on their wishlist.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mCourts are generally loath to grant relief when the outcome wouldn't change. ("Void as moot.")⁣

  [1mjseliger[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mA big problem that divides us is property renters versus owners: owners have spent the last several decades
  [0mrestricting access to property, and that's now raised the cost of the most productive metro areas to
  [0munacceptable levels: [34mwww.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2012/03/the-ren…[0m Many millions of people, especially
  [0mbut not exclusively the young, have in effect been gated out of prosperity.
  [0m
  [0mMatt Yglesias's new book [3mOne Billion Americans[0m has a good discussion of the issue:
  [0m[34mnymag.com/intelligencer/2020/08/one-billion-american…[0m, even if you don't buy his population-based premise.
  [0m
  [0mUntil we can free our land markets, we're going to have a lot of political problems caused by people who
  [0m(correctly) feel they can't afford to live.

   [1mmshumi[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIs it fair if people can be restricted from competing in the property markets by people who faced no such⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrestrictions themselves when acquiring that land capital. Zoning licensing, etc.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe elephant in the room is that for most people the majority of their net worth is tied up in housing⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m(property) and as interest rates drop the nominal value of this property increases way faster than the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mnominal wages of labor. This property can then be used to create information insensitive debt that ignores⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0many notion of liquidity at an artificially higher nominal value. This debt is then used to pay wage-labor who⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mincreasingly cannot acquire property themselves. At the end of the day, only real property is wealth (land,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mip rights, equity, collectibles, and machinery) and labor is denied the opportunity to earn a larger share of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mproperty themselves. Any solution is politically difficult.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mtachyonbeam[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI agree that there is an issue with housing being so inaccessible to labor. In my city, even with a six⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfigure salary, it's hard to buy something alone. You increasingly need two six figure plus salaries to make⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mit work. IMO, part of the problem is that everyone views housing as an investment. People trade real estate⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mlike trading cards. We forget that homes have a more fundamental purpose (to house people).⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIf you can't afford a home, as a way to get your foot in the door, you can buy ETFs on the stock market. You⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcan also buy REITs as a way to invest in real estate. There are even diversified REIT ETFs. It's like being⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0ma landlord, you get paid dividends, but you don't have to lift a finger. If someone has some money on the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mside but can't yet afford property, this is a relatively safe way to get into investing and the real estate⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmarket IMO.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe unfortunate difference though is that mortgage rates are subsidized by the government, interest rates⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mare kept artificially low. If you get a mortgage to buy a property, it's effectively leveraged investing.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mYou pay a small downpayment (as low as 10% nowadays) and you're basically investing with someone else's⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmoney. You can't do that with REITs. Nobody will lend you 10X your downpayment at 2% interest to buy ETFs.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIf you can't afford to own property, you are denied this leveraged investing opportunity.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPersonally, as a condo owner, I would be OK with condo prices not going up. As prices increases, so do my⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtaxes. I can just invest in the stock market. I don't need my home to be an investment, I just need it to be⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0ma comfortable place to live.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mjelliclesfarm[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mPeople want to own residential units. Ownership is and should be more expensive than occupancy.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mA residential unit also needs power, sewer, water, schools, fire dept, police dept, parks and recreation,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msanitation and other services, transportation, commerce, infrastructure and roads. And staff to run all⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthis. Building up vertically on a x30 multiplier doesn’t mean that city can provide all the services and⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0maccess resources to service the multiplier effect of said parcel of land. This is why high density cities⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mend up being unaffordable.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIf high density cities are built up to accommodate more affordable homes and below market value homes, the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mresidents effectively pay negative taxes by benefitting more from the city than they pay in as taxes. The⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmath doesn’t work out. If it did, we would have more townships with high density as well as⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0maffordability..and cost of living going down. But in my observation,such things never happen. At least from⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe data I had collated from Bay Area cities. I would love to be proved wrong.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe only way..as I see it..high density home ownership can be feasible is if we have clustered communities⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mbetween 150-300 households and each of the homes comes with assured employment. It’s closer to ‘company⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mtowns’ or military townships.⁣

  [0m
  [0m1. The US, by the most generally accepted definition, has had continuous governance as a democracy since 1788.
  [0mJust one more election, and not the most contentious or momentous by a long shot.
  [0m
  [0m2. Current reported spread in votes between D and R are pretty slim, 75.0M v. 70.7M Wikipedia 11PM EST 11/7.
  [0m
  [0m3. Whatever your partisan opinion, at least 70M American adults, 48.5% of those voting, disagree with you and
  [0mthink you’re an idiot. Try not to confirm the fact with your comments.
  [0m
  [0m4. Challenging the validity of the voting process is a time-honored tradition during tight races. Stop
  [0msounding like newbies. This is the only time that the validity of the electoral process gets enough visibility
  [0mto figure out if anything’s broke. Seriously broke? See 1.
  [0m
  [0m5. A paper trail is a beautiful thing.
  [0m
  [0m6. And what a wonderfully fertile field these comments are for use as examples of propaganda, inflammatory
  [0mrhetoric and logical fallacies. Wish I was teaching a course right about now. Timely for the application of
  [0mmanure on fields too…
  [0m
  [0m7. It would be nice if the mods kept the discussion away from an r/politics-ization of HN. The sides are
  [0mpretty obvious and enforcing an arbitrary quota of half blue hurrah/half red hurrah would lead to a better
  [0mflow and balance. Heavy-handed, but appropriate in these few cases IMHO.
  [0m
  [0mThe brilliant, stupid, wise, foolish, angry, mellow, old, young, rich, poor, naive, cynical, kind, nasty,
  [0msophisticated, brutish American people have spoken. Whether you agree with the results or not, it’s a
  [0mbeautiful thing.

  [1mchmod600[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mA voting system needs to be accurate but it also needs to inspire confidence. I think the U.S. failed on the
  [0mlatter point. Let me be clear that I don't think this affected the [3moutcome[0m, only the [3mconfidence in the[0m
  [0m[3moutcome[0m.
  [0m
  [0mMail-in voting has existed for a long time, but it is being done at a larger scale and in new ways and new
  [0mplaces. It was a mistake to do it during such a contentious election. Covid is not a good enough reason: it's
  [0measy enough to drop the ballot in a county box so the secretary of state has a chain of custody for all valid
  [0mballots. I would actually prefer voter ID as well as people standing there to do a brief check. In addition to
  [0mpreventing fraud, it also helps remind voters if they forgot to sign or something.
  [0m
  [0mAlso, I think it needs to be said that a lot of people hate Trump. Hate can cause people to do things that
  [0mthey would never imagine doing otherwise, like election fraud. It doesn't need to be a conspiracy… just a lot
  [0mof individuals doing small stuff (post office employees throwing away likely Trump ballots, etc.).
  [0m
  [0mAnd it doesn't help that the map looked quite red on the day of the election, and that the poll numbers were
  [0mWAY off, and that the media was rooting for Biden. It all just erodes confidence.

  [1mcharliemil4[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mWe should trust but verify the results. The basis of facts should be settled in the following:
  [0m
  [0m1. Select all ballots that were sent to the same address - or sent to the same Post Office (grouping all PO
  [0mBoxes by post office).
  [0m^ Here you are trying to see if there is systemic voting behaviors out of the ordinary — i.e. did 10+ ballots
  [0mgo to one address.
  [0m
  [0m2. Select all ballots that were sent to an alternate address than the voter registration.
  [0m^ This is a general query — select a sample set of these and confirm with the registered voter that they did
  [0mindeed receive a mail in ballot.
  [0m
  [0m3. If above is inconclusive, select all registered voters that requested a mail in ballot against the
  [0m2017-2018 Equifax Data to determine if correlations occur.
  [0m
  [0m4. Select all ballots that were the voter did not vote in the last X elections (there are political
  [0mconsultancies that provide information on who NOT to waste your time on because they do not vote), did these
  [0mpeople request a mail in ballot? Were these ballots sent to an alternate address?
  [0m
  [0mFor clarification [[31m1[0m], if one were armed with a SSN or DL and a previous address, one could request a ballot
  [0mon behalf of another person AND have that ballot redirected to a location of their choosing… including a PO
  [0mBox. The form is included here for reference.
  [0m
  [0m[[31m1[0m] [34mwww.votespa.com/Register-to-Vote/Documents/PADOS_Mai…[0m
  [0m
  [0mEDIT: just so you know, I think both of them did things like this. I want my d%mn democracy back.

                                                   [1m▶ 42 replies[0m                                                 ‌
                                                   [1;2m▼ 42 replies[0m                                                 ⁣
  ⁣
   [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mVoting fraud on the scale required to influence a US election is not possible due to voting registration⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrequirements. Registering any significant amount of fake people is not feasible, and if you are trying to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcast the votes of any significant number of real people you will quickly have a collision with someone who⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mactually does intend on voting, leading to an investigation and the whole scheme unraveling.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mVoter registration + signature checks + investigating duplicate ballots is a robust system for ensuring that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msystematic voting fraud can only achieve a small result without being overwhelmingly likely to be caught. If⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe election had actually come down to a margin of a few thousand votes in a single state it might have been⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mworth the resources to do a deep-dive, but with the margins that occurred we can be certain that voting fraud⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdid not influence the result.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe election boards of each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia do in fact conduct regular⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0maudits, and frequently purge voter rolls of registered voters that have been sufficiently inactive as to be⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msuspected of having died or moved out of the state. You may have read about such events in previous months⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0min the national news.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI don’t see why I would care much if there is voting fraud if I can be certain that it did not influence⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe result. What does it harm me if an election decided by a margin of tens of thousands of votes had some⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mfew hundreds or even thousands of illegitimate ballots cast? It’s a tiny amount of noise in a very strong⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msignal. It’s easy for a state to estimate what percentage of the vote could possibly have been fraudulent,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mand when the signal seems to be at risk of being lost in the noise there is a robust process of signal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mrecovery. But recounts are expensive and a waste of time and resources when they are not needed.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mIm not from the US, but my understanding of the alleged fraud is that due to coronavirus many states sent⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mevery[0m registered voter a blank ballot (where in the past they explicitely had to request a ballot) and that,⁣

     [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI’ll lead off by mentioning that some states already voted by mail and have for many years. So if there⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwere a problem with this approach that enabled mass voter fraud we would be well aware by now.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe “blank ballots” are not blank in the sense that they are interchangeable. Each ballot sent out is the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mspecific ballot of a specific person. It’s certainly possible that some ballots were stolen from their⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mintended recipients and mailed back with forged signatures, but what’s important is whether this could have⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mbeen done on a mass scale to influence the election result. And the answer to that is no. A coordinated⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0meffort to fraudulently return enough ballots to matter would require large-scale raiding of mailboxes to⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msteal ballots, or stealing ballots in mass quantity soon after they were put into the postal system by each⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mstate’s election commission. The former is impossible, as it would require an organization comparable in⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0msize to the postal service to be able to go house by house stealing ballots as they were delivered, and it⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mwould be obvious that it was occurring. The latter is easy to detect and trivial to rectify.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIn both cases, the fraud would be detected as soon as anyone who hadn’t received their ballot went to their⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mstate’s election website and requested another ballot and were informed that their ballot had been⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdelivered and returned.⁣
  ⁣
     [1mjustin66[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mWhen it comes to fraud, obtaining a ballot is as easy as obtaining a bank check, for example. It's legal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m(in my state, anyway) for various parties to distribute them, and you could print your own, if you had the⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mright paper. (You'd be in hot water if your ballot wasn't the exact document the state distributes - it's a⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcrime to distribute a ballot that's prepopulated with the user's data, for example)⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe security features of the process do not depend on mail-in ballots being unique or scarce.⁣
  ⁣

     [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIt is certainly true that the US is frequently behind the curve of other first world nations on government⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdeployment of new technology. This is largely because of 2 reasons. Reason #1, the US historically is⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mfrequently the first place technologies are deployed on a wide scale, and as a result the US generally has⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe earliest and thus the worst version of everything. Reason #2, the US system of federated States⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mintroduces great friction into any system requiring a central authority.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThe absence of a national voter ID program perfectly exemplifies this. The US has an election system that⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mworks sufficiently well, so there’s no major impetus to overhaul how voters vote. And the US Federal⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mgovernment doesn’t even [3mhave[0m a list of all US citizens. In fact, no such list even exists. Moreover, a lack⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mof any existing documentation that a person is a citizen does not necessarily mean that they are not a⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcitizen due to birthright citizenship or citizenship automatically inherited from parents.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mConcerns about voter suppression induced by the introduction of a national voter ID are completely⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mlegitimate. The US Federal government lacks the capacity to ensure that every eligible voter is delivered⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0man ID (lacking a list of all citizens), so the burden to acquire one falls on the individual. If this costs⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmoney, then it constitutes an unconstitutional poll tax. And in any case, since the Federal government is⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mincapable of handling such a responsibility it would fall to the individual states, some of which have⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mdemonstrated historically that they will act to make the process arbitrarily difficult for individuals that⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthe sitting state legislature would prefer do not vote.⁣
  ⁣

    [1mzjs[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mIt's been a constant stream of catastrophizing from them for the last four years.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI've looked at a few definitions, and I don't see how it's an accurate description of what's happening here.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mFor example: “Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion that prompts people to jump to the worst possible⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mconclusion, usually with very limited information or objective reason to despair. When a situation is⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mupsetting, but not necessarily catastrophic, they still feel like they are in the midst of a crisis.”⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m([34mwww.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/catastrophizing[0m)⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mWe have experienced “great damage or suffering” (i.e., catastrophes), not merely upsetting situations. The⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmedia hasn't been catastrophizing; they've been reporting about catastrophes.⁣

    [1mhn_throwaway_99[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mMy pet theory is similar, but slightly more nuanced, and comes from my history of being harshly bullied in⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmiddle school.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe group dynamics of bullying are pretty straightforward. There will always be bullies at the top who want⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mto cement their status by showing their power as a bully. To get a significant group of people to go along⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwith the bullying, however, (think everyone laughing along when the bully makes fun of someone) that group⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mneeds to be really unsure of their place in the social hierarchy. They know bullying is wrong but at that⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpoint are somewhat terrified of ending up on the wrong side of the bullying. That's why you see so much⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbullying in middle school, where kids are usually just starting to find their place in the social hierarchy.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI think in the US (and many Western democracies) there is currently so much unease about economics, about⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mfinding a good, and more importantly, stable job, that the situation is ripe for a bully to come along and⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtake advantage of people's general worries about their place in the world to think "better for me to be a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mbully myself than to be the person that ends up on the bottom of the totem pole". Think of the crowd⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mlaughing along when Trump mocked a reporter with cerebral palsy.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mWhen you couple this with large, structural racial changes in the US, it's not hard to see how Trump was⁣

     [1mseanmcdirmid[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThat reminds me of the McGregor’s legacy joke (a bit vulgar but⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[34mwww.reddit.com/r/Jokes/comments/feuz6/whats_that_jok…[0m). The gist is that people are noted for the⁣

    [0m[32m▎[0mexposure, impressions, and engagement are sold to the highest bidders on social media platforms. Not only⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mthat, the platforms allow fine-grained targeting of users based on tomes of data collected on them.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mThese recommender systems don't just hijack people's attentions as a side effect of increasing engagement,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mit is by design in pathologically manipulative and anti-user way.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mIt isn't a coincidence that those with money and an agenda[[33m2[0m] can inject money into social media platforms⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mand have their content spread like wildfire.⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[[31m1[0m] [34mkelleycotter.com//wp-content/uploads/2020/02/IJoC_Al…[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[[33m2[0m] [34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Mercer#Brexit[0m⁣
  ⁣
     [1md10r[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mCould there be a class action lawsuit against the various companies whose recommendation engines hijacked[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mpeople's attention to recommend and reinforce this garbage?[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0m⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mI think this thought is spot on. The usual defense is "but free speech!". Which would boil down to: "such⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mis human nature". But I don't believe that's the problem. The problem may indeed be selection and⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mamplification mechanisms like recommendation engines tuned to divert max. attention to the medium,⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mmasterfully exploiting the vulnerabilities of the human psyche as evolution formed it. The rest is⁣
    [0m[32m▎[0mcollateral damage which nobody seems to feel responsible for. Not a sustainable situation.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mKye[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mCarl Sagan had a good, relevant story in his "Why we need to understand science":⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mI read it in one of his books, but this is the only good version I can find online.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mPDF: [34mplaza.ufl.edu/trishak/Carl%20Sagan%20-%20Why%20We%20N…[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mFrom Parade Magazine, September 10, 1989 – As I got off the plane, he was waiting for me, holding up a[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3msign with my name on it. I was on my way to a conference of scientists and TV broadcasters, and the[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3morganizers had kindly sent a driver.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2m"Do you mind if I ask you a question?" He said as we waited for my bag. "Isn't it confusing to have the[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3msame name as that science guy?"[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mIt took me a moment to understand. Was he pulling my leg? "I am that science guy," I said. He smiled.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3m"Sorry. That's my problem. I thought it was yours too." He put out his hand. "My name is William F.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mBuckley." (Well, his name wasn't exactly William F. Buckley, but he did have the name of a contentious TV[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3minterviewer, for which he doubtless took a lot of good-natured ribbing.)[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mAs we settled into the car for the long drive, he told me he was glad I was "that science guy" — he had so[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mmany questions to ask about science. Would I mind? And so we got to talking. But not about science. He[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mwanted to discuss UFOs, "channeling" (a way to hear what's on the minds of dead people — not much it turns[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mout), crystals, astrology … He introduced each subject with real enthusiasm, and each time I had to[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mdisappoint him: "The evidence is crummy," I kept saying. "There's a much simpler explanation." As we drove[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mon through the rain, I could see him getting glummer. I was attacking not just pseudoscience but also a[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mfacet of his inner life.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mAnd yet there is so much in real science that's equally exciting, more mysterious, a greater intellectual[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mchallenge—as well as being a lot closer to the truth. Did he know about the molecular building blocks of[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mlife sitting out there in the cold tenuous gas between the stars? Had he heard of the footprints of our[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mancestors found in 4-mil-lion-year-old volcanic ash? What about the raising of the Himalayas when India[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mwent crashing into Asia? Or how viruses subvert cells, or the radio search for extraterrestrial[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mintelligence or the ancient civilization of Ebla? Mr. "Buckley" — well-spoken, intelligent, curious — had[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mheard virtually nothing of modem science. He wanted to know about science. It's just that all the science[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mgot filtered out before it reached him. What the society permitted to trickle through was mainly pretense[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mand confusion. And it had never taught him how to distinguish real science from the cheap imitation.[0m⁣
  ⁣

  [1mbetwixthewires[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mFor a site full of engineers I'm surprised to see the discussion center on partisan politics, talking points,
  [0munsourced claims and demands for sources, bickering over every detail, when what I'd want to talk about among
  [0mtechnical people is the fact that Biden hasn't actually won, based on the rules of the system. He claimed he
  [0mwon. So did Trump. Neither are backed by anything tangible, yet. It looks like the PA AG has called for a
  [0mstatewide audit of votes, several court orders have been issued in several states, including Michigan and
  [0mWisconsin, there are lawsuits in several jurisdictions, and recounts in Georgia and Nevada are going to start
  [0msoon. Notice how I'm not saying the lawsuits and accusations are founded, because I'd like to talk about the
  [0msystem.
  [0m
  [0mThis is far from over. You could have votes invalidated. This is only over when the electors travel to DC and
  [0m270+ vote for one person. That could be halted. You could see the house delegations vote, you could see state
  [0mor federal courts rule, you could even see some state legislative bodies make decisions on it.
  [0m
  [0mIt takes a lot more than a claim of victory and a news organization calling it for an election to be over, and
  [0mI'd expect a bunch of very smart people to know that.

   [1mbaumandm[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mI'm not sure why you think people don't realize this.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIt is well-established tradition for both news organizations to call races and the apparent loser to concede,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mwell in advance of December 14th.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mBiden's lead in both the electoral votes and the state margins means that in order for Trump to win, he would⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mneed to flip multiple states. Recounts typically only move a few hundred votes, and his legal challenges⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhaven't seen any traction.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSo yes, it's technically not over yet, but it is incredibly unlikely to have any other outcome.⁣
  ⁣
   [1mdragonwriter[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mThis is only over when the electors travel to DC[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe electors do not, in fact, travel to DC, at all. [[37m0[0m]⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mand 270+ vote for one person.[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIf you are going to be excessively legalistic, it's not over until the electoral votes are reviewed, judged,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtallied, and reported by Congress. On the other hand, by design, by law, and by established practice, in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mvarious combinations for the various components, pretty much all of that process after the public vote and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtallying is ministerial rather than discretionary; and the established practices for transition of power in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0man open seat or incumbent defeat situation very much rely on proceeding based on the known outcome before all⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe various ministerial acts are completed.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[[37m0[0m] [34mwww.archives.gov/electoral-college/roles#meeting[0m “On the first Monday after the second Wednesday in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mDecember, [3mthe electors meet in their respective States[0m to cast their votes for President and Vice President⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mof the United States.” [emphasis added]⁣

    [1mcgrealy[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mthere's nothing that's going to stop climate change except the free market agreeing to pursue[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3msustainability.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThat is exactly the attitude that got us into this situation in the first place.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe free market will NEVER voluntarily choose compliance costs. The value simply isn't there.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThe free market is an engine to optimise profit. That's it. All other considerations are secondary.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mWhile there is a market niche for "ethical products", that is ultimately (and somewhat ironically)⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0munsustainable without regulation.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mIf I start a business behaving ethically, using renewable energy, paying my employees and suppliers a fair⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwage, etc… my only hope is that I can attract a niche market that will pay a premium for that. But history⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhas shown us that is simply not the case.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mRegulation levels the playing field. Otherwise, we would still have child labour, weekend work, dangerous⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mworking conditions, etc.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAs for the argument that other countries will ignore this: 1: other countries AREN'T ignoring this. The US⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mis the one that pulled out of Paris 2: The US is the still the biggest economy in the world. If the US⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mgovernment imposed regulations that all business must act in a sustainable fashion (including the supply⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mchain) the rest of the world would have to follow through.⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mit doesn't have a common culture, the struggles are that it has too many veto points in its political process⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mso it is extremely difficult for popular majorities to execute on a political vision, and it is extremely⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdifficult for the population of the country to hold their leaders accountable when the multiple veto points⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mlead to a diffusion of responsibility. The struggle we have is that popular majorities cannot enact their⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpolicy preferences, and then do not receive electoral feedback based on the policies they enact. America⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdoesn't need a common culture, it needs a better feedback loop for things to go from idea -> popular will ->⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpolitical power -> policy change -> impact on the people.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mnojvek[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThis ^ 100%. Sure the election process may be democratic but the way bills and laws are passed are not. The⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mpower is in a handful of people who don’t represent the will of people. Instead we’ll see painful 4 years⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwhere things get blocked on the merit of “Democrats wrote this bill therefore it must be rejected and vice⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mversa”.⁣

   [1mganeshkrishnan[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNeither Switzerland nor Singapore has a unified culture. People from German speaking Zurich are not the same⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mas french Speaking Geneva or Bern. Likewise for Singapore there is a community of Tamils, Malays, Chinese⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0metc. I grew up in extremely multicultural environment and can assure you that there were no identity issues.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThese issues popup once class/money imbalance pops up.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAt the root of it all is wealth disparity. The rest of it is just a facade.⁣

   [1mchrchang523[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSomeone who was e.g. raised as a Christian, and then concluded that some of the stories they were told in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSunday School were lies, is likely to treat an appeal to religious authority as evidence [3magainst[0m a claim.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEven in domains where Christian groups have been effective in practice.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe same can be said about mainstream media or science.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIn the short term, it's practically impossible to reach such people without identifying somewhere they're⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mactually right in their rejection of the mainstream narrative, and gaining their trust by recognizing that.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mOnly with that trust do you have a shot of being listened to when you point out where they overcorrected⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0magainst the mainstream narrative.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIn the longer term, it would really help if some key mainstream narratives became more accurate. Without⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat, "getting out of the country" may actually become the best option for an increasing number of people.⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mpopular position because most people simply [3mdon't want to know how dark the world really is[0m. The framing of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mEpstein as some one off independent abuser is actually part of the coverup of just one middle manager in one⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mof said blackmail rings. He ran girls, others run boys. Top level politicians and businessmen are targets for⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mleverage. If you balk at even this assertion just because of the "crazy by association" to pizzagate, take⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe time to lookup: The Dutroux Affair, aka Belgiums X-Files, The Franklin Scandal, the Finders Scandal, Roy⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mCohn (Trumps mentor)… as just a start. Also note: wikipedia will not provide good information on these kinds⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mof topics. If one were to look at the entry for the Franklin Scandal without digging further, one would⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mprobably walk away thinking it was a hoax, which isn't the truth at all.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mOn the topic of psyops, one of the most used techniques is called the "limited hangout". I usually use the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mflat earth conspiracy as an example of this. Of course it is quite assinine, and should generally just be⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mignored as such, an analysis will show that those who talk about it (I would posit are often not organic),⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0malso talk about much more legitimate conspiracy theories. The intent is to make the more legitimate⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconspiracy theories [3mdiscredited as crazy by association[0m. Qanon is such an operation. It took what could have⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbeen a movement against the blackmail networks that have infiltrated and compromised huge amounts of business⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mand politicians [3mon both sides of the isle[0m, and turned it into a partisan, quasi-religious outlet that goes⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mnowhere, but always promises something is about to happen (keeping the partipants hopeful and distracted from⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmore meaningful action) with the added side-bonus of being one of the best honeypots for metadata on those⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtypes in existence.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe Bill Gates topic is another good example. It's easy to kneejerk dismiss those concerns as they sound⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mquite outlandish… but again, there is at least a modicum of truth, or rather, a handful of reasons people⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mshould be much more skeptical of the intentions of Bill Gates on the topic. For example, Bill Gates had quite⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0man extensive relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, something a cursory search on the topic from mainstream⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msources will give nothing more than a passing mention. He had a relatively sordid relationship with the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpharma industry in India, one worth digging into. On the "microchip" thing, another great example. Gate's⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrelated foundations and companies have openly talked about the quantum dot system, which is just readable⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmarkers to identify who has had a particular vaccine, and have actively partnered with the pentagon and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdarpa, and the ID2020 program is being tested on newborns in Bangladesh and homelss people in Austin, TX⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0malready. Those kinds of assocation alone are enough to at least empathize and understand where those who then⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtake that and buy into the microchips story are coming from. So while it's untrue that the Gate's linked⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mprograms intend to put microchips in, the talk of digital certificates linked to biometrics such as quantum⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdot scare people, and then combine that with the fact that DARPA and the pentagon [3mhave been investigating[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[3msuch microchips[0m, along with a history of medically experimenting on humans without consent, it's easy to see⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe jump to conclusions being made.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mGiven the huge amount of propaganda being heaped on the American public from all sides then, I think you⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mshould reconsider judging so harshly those who have fallen victim to that propaganda, and instead should⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfocus on the purveyors and originators of that propaganda. To be frank, I also find this disproportionate⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mjudging of people in the current day to be very unprincipled also. We can invade countries illegally, murder⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhundreds of thousands of people abroad… and crickets… but talk about how the same engine that did that abroad⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mis now turning it's eye of sauron back towards us, inward, and you must be a batshit crazy conspiracy⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtheorist. To just now be losing faith in America/it's people is myopic at best. Try to judge a bit less, and⁣

  ⁣
   [1mgreggyb[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe Constitution of the United States is a document written to preserve co-equal sovereignty of a bunch of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mstates that wanted to be closer to nations than provinces, while avoiding the then-very-apparent risk of⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcentralized absolute governing authority.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe framers of the Constitution didn't get everything right, but it's very useful to keep that perspective in⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmind when trying to understand the form of the US government.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIf you take the perspective of states as sovereign, with federation between them, then the Electoral College⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mstarts to make a lot more sense. The goal was to preserve the power of a [3mstate[0m in the federal government, as⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mmuch as to represent the collection of people from all states - both concepts were critical. The idea is that⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mpeople from the nation deserve representation [3mand[0m that each state (and the people from that state as a⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msub-population) deserve representation.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIf federation of states is a core concept of the subdivision of governing responsibility, then it makes sense⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mto build a system that ensures each state has meaningful weight in the governance of that federation.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mNone of this is an argument for or against the Electoral College, nor should it be interpreted as arguing for⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthe correctness/effectiveness/righteousness/morality of the institution. It is simply an attempt to share⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mperspective to help understand why the system is the way it is.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAs originally defined, the House of Representatives was the only piece of the federal government intended to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdirectly represent the people of the nation. Senators were originally chosen by state legislatures. The⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mSenate was intended to represent the states, not the people directly.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe Electoral College was an intermediary to represent both the states and the people - as a compromise, it⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhas many failings that seem obvious today. There is no federal mandate as to how a state's electors choose to⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcast their votes. Each state is responsible for regulating its own voting - this includes how people vote⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mand how electors are chosen and how those electors vote. It is mere happenstance that the majority of states⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhave a winner-takes-all allotment strategy for their electors. Maine and Nebraska notably assign their⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0melectors proportionally.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mIt is also interesting to note that the tie-breaking mechanism for an Electoral College tie devolves to the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mHouse, not with one vote per representative, but with one vote per state. This is another example of the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mconcept that [3mstates[0m are a concept deserving of representation.⁣
  ⁣
   [1mceilingcorner[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe US is not and was never supposed to be a popular vote democracy. The founding fathers recognized the⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdangers of populism and subsequently made sure that the government is a republic.⁣
  ⁣
    [1mGwypaas[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mMichael Barbaro: [3mSo this winner-take-all system, this is not something envisioned by the framers. It seems[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mlike it kind of came to us in a pretty haphazard way.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mJesse Wegman: [3mRight. People like to imagine that the system that we used today was handed down to us from[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mthe framers. And in fact, the framers didn’t talk at all about the winner-take-all rule. It didn’t come up[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mat the convention. And when they saw it start to be adopted in the states in the early 1800s, they were[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mhorrified. James Madison, the man we think of as the father of the Constitution, tried to pass a[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3mconstitutional amendment prohibiting the use of winner-take-all rule because he saw how corrosive it was to[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[3merase up to half of voters in the state.[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[34mwww.nytimes.com/2020/10/22/podcasts/the-daily/electo…[0m⁣
  ⁣
    [1mkrapp[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mThe founding fathers recognized the dangers of populism and subsequently made sure that the government is[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3ma republic.[0m⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mYeah, umm… about that…⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe whole point is to prevent Germany and France (or New York and California) from dominating everything.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mminority.⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mdue to the potential for fraud. So even today, the electoral college serves as a safeguard when there is⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mreason to believe the popular vote has been tainted. The current media narrative is there is no hard⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mevidence, but what other evidence other than video, sworn affidavits is required? Do not be too quick to call⁣

  [0m[31m▎[0mIs it flagged? Mostly, I think people just don't care that much because Benford's law is a curious pattern⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthat applies to some kinds of numbers some of the time, so it's interesting as a first diagnostic of fraud,⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mbut without an argument of why it applies to this particular kind of data, and without further investigation⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mof what might be causing the irregularity, it's not a smoking gun by any means.⁣

   [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mRevising our electoral system to change the incentives for political parties and politicians would be an⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mapproach. Winner-take-all on a state by state basis with single-party primaries produce candidates who are⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mfar from the median voter and then campaign to drum up support among their party base. Universal primary⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0msystems encourage candidates with broader appeal outside of their party to end up as the party nominee, who⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthen have a much easier time running a general election campaign on appealing to opposition party voters⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mrather than being forced by the positions they took in their primary to campaign only to boost turnout among⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mtheir existing base.⁣
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

  [1mthrowawayx7[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mSomething that should be addressed as soon as possible is reducing the capacity of foreign actors to influence
  [0mpolitics through organized trolling.
  [0m
  [0mThere has been a lot of gaslighting around this issue, but the fact is that the United States has been
  [0mprotected by two vast oceans for its entire history, but it opened a conduit into its heartland for foreign
  [0mmischief-makers through Facebook and Twitter. Whether it helped Trump or not in 2016 (frankly, I think it
  [0mprobably did but it's exhausting to debate this so I won't) it does represent a gaping hole in America's
  [0mdefenses.
  [0m
  [0mUntil this election, there seemed to be a clear pattern (in the English speaking world anyway) that allowed
  [0mone to reliably predict the winner of an election by seeing which side the trolls supported.
  [0m
  [0mThere are no First Amendment protections for Russian/Iranian/Macedonian click or troll farms. Detecting VPNs
  [0mand other attempts to conceal traffic is not an insurmountable technical challenge, yet it isn't done
  [0mconsistently.
  [0m
  [0mThe seductive "Arab Spring" approach to letting free speech run rampant on social media turned out to be a
  [0mmirage. Not only was the Arab Spring reversed in Egypt, based on my discussions with Egyptians, Facebook was
  [0mturned into a tool of repression after the counter-revolution took hold.
  [0m
  [0m(Yes, the irony of posting this from a throwaway account doesn't escape me, but there's a difference between
  [0mclearly anonymous speech, and speech that misrepresents its source).
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

  [1mjustinzollars[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mBiden will be the First Democrat since Grover Cleveland to take office without a Democratic Senate. The House
  [0mmajority is smaller. So his mandate is effectively toast. Another interesting historical fact. America has
  [0mnever elected 4 consecutive 2 term presidents. If Trump would have been elected it would have been the first
  [0mtime in US history that this has happened. This election wasn't a blue wave by any means, Trump underperformed
  [0mHouse Republicans in many swing states implying this was more of a personal decision rather than political.
  [0m
  [0mWhat do I see changing? Not much:
  [0m
  [0m[2m  - foreign policy: policy changes with Syria and Iran[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - China: An end to tariffs[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - local changes: No more federal opposition to safe injection sites in San Francisco[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - federal taxes could still go up, the Senate has two liberal Republicans who could deliver tax increases to Joe[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - expanded federal regulations that do not require changes to the law[0m
  [0m
  [0mWhat will likely not happen:
  [0m
  [0m[2m  - PR and DC becoming states is no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - packing the Supreme Court is no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - a green new deal or expansions to entitlements are no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - state bailouts are now in question, which could force major structural reforms[0m

   [1mcblconfederate[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe Doge wasn't selected randomly, but via a series of randomized election rounds in order to ensure that no⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mcoordination was possible. Wiki has a fun description:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[3m[2mThirty members of the Great Council, chosen by lot, were reduced by lot to nine; the nine chose forty and[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mthe forty were reduced by lot to twelve, who chose twenty-five. The twenty-five were reduced by lot to[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mnine, and the nine elected forty-five. These forty-five were once more reduced by lot to eleven, and the[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3meleven finally chose the forty-one who elected the doge.[19] Election required at least twenty-five votes[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[2m ▎[2;3mout of forty-one, nine votes out of eleven or twelve, or seven votes out of nine electors.[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAncient Athens appointed most offices by lot, they even had a democracy machine:⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m[34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleroterion[0m⁣
  [2m▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁[0m

  [1mjimnotgym[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mPlease permit me a ramble, there are too many points to fit in a hn box and I'm typing on a phone.
  [0m
  [0mI'm sure our stateside friends would be happy to acknowledge that US politics has a major effect on the whole
  [0mworld. I have had it pointed out to me before, however, that the USA can vote in whomever they please, and it
  [0mis none of our business.
  [0m
  [0mBut American companies sell us our books and films (understatement), take cuts of our credit card payments,
  [0mmake us coffee, organize our taxis. All of this seems to be with preferential tax treatment. All of these
  [0mthings could be done without the US, but the US is our partner in peace, so it is tolerated.
  [0m
  [0mAnd here is the rub, this works so long as the USA is a legitimate ally.
  [0m
  [0mAnd then came Trump, telling us that we don't spend enough on Nato (with US defence companies) and threatening
  [0mour peace. I believe this has lead to a situation where the US is seen less as a partner and more as a bully,
  [0ma colonial overlord demanding tribute. I think the next 20 years will see a shift in this kind of trade to the
  [0mEU and to the East.
  [0m
  [0mThe USA can be insular if it wants, but it can't do so and expect everything to be the same as it has been for
  [0mthe last 50 years. An insular US is a declining US. Your new President has a terrific amount of work to do to
  [0mundo this damage…

    [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mTrue, but on a deeper level NATO most of all serves US interests, and Joe Biden will grumble but happily⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcontinue to subsidize the defense of member nations.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mThese days NATO is most clearly recognized as a list of countries that the USA as global military hegemon is⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mready to go to war to defend, and this is hugely beneficial to a country that wants to be a global military⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mhegemon. Wars are expensive and ideally you don’t want to fight any. The existence of an organization like⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mNATO means that (a) none of the member nations are going to fight each other, (b) none of the member nations⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mare going to try to rival the military hegemon, (c) nobody outside of the organization is going to start a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mwar with any of the members. For a military hegemon whose main interest is ensuring global peace so that it⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mcan continue to reap the rewards of a global economic system that it is also hegemon over, getting to mark⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0moff a large chunk of the developed world as “no wars here” is well worth paying for. In a very, very loose⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0msense it’s sorta like an olden-days imperial power with tributaries, but the “tribute” is realized in the⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mform of the fact that the US government’s position as military and economic hegemon means that it can⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mmanufacture dollars for free and other countries will trade goods and services for them.⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0m⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mOn top of that, concentrating the defense spending of the alliance within the US is good for the US economy⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mand critically important for maintaining the R&D efforts that the US military relies on to maintain a⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mtechnological edge over potential rivals outside of the alliance.⁣
  ⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mme than it used to.⁣

   [0m[33m▎[0mdefect in me. This is a situation where our popular imagery doesn't really match reality for the majority of⁣
   [0m[33m▎[0mAmericans.⁣

  [1mbeloch[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mAs a Canadian, what stands out for me about the last two elections is that many Americans seem to desperately
  [0mwant a variety of political reforms, but neither party seems interested in providing them. Trump and Sanders
  [0mboth sold themselves as reform candidates in 2016, but only Trump wound up on the ticket.
  [0m
  [0mSanders might be the real deal, but he's not going to represent a major party until donation and campaign
  [0mspending limits (like we have in Canada) reduce corporate influence on U.S. politics. Sanders scares away the
  [0m"big money" that U.S. elections depend so heavily on.
  [0m
  [0mTrump has not proven to be a reform candidate in any sense of the word. As a political outsider with control
  [0mover both the house and senate for his first two years in office, he had the power to deliver meaningful
  [0mreforms, but didn't. Americans desiring reform [3mshould[0m have felt deeply betrayed by Trump's first term.
  [0m
  [0mThe democrats had a smoother primary in 2020, but decided on an utterly bland candidate. Biden is a return to
  [0mthe status-quo. I predicted that, after the last four years, a return to the status quo would appeal to many,
  [0mbut this election proves otherwise. This [3mshould[0m have been an [3measy[0m slam dunk for the Democrats to win, but it's
  [0mturned out to be a squeaker!
  [0m
  [0mIf the democrats ride the status quo for the next four years and both parties were to run the same candidates
  [0magain, I suspect Biden would lose. The Democrats need to pay attention to what Americans want.
  [0m
  [0mI would suggest that Biden's administration should, despite running on a thoroughly status-quo platform,
  [0m[3membrace[0m reform. Too many Americans mistrust their own political system, to the point that they're willing to
  [0mpicket polling stations because they think fraud is being committed. That must be fixed. Finding ways to
  [0mreduce the influence of money on politics (e.g. campaign spending limits) would be a good start. It will also
  [0mbe an easy sell to devolve and distribute some of the powers that have accumulated in the white house over the
  [0mlast several decades. If you're not comfortable with some of the powers Trump wielded during his time in
  [0moffice, then perhaps those powers shouldn't rest with the POTUS.
  [0m
  [0mBottom line, if the democrats try to pretend Trump [3mnever[0m happened and [3mcouldn't[0m happen again, they're in for
  [0munpleasant surprises.

   [1mSvip[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mThe Electoral College votes on the first Monday after the 2nd Wednesday in December; so the 14th. What⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mhappens on 6 January is Congress ratifying the electoral votes.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mAnd it's the state legislatures that effectively elect their state's electors, which needs to be done before⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m14 December.⁣
  ⁣

   [1med25519FUUU[0m [2m9 months ago[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mDec 14th is a better deadline to watch. That's the date at which a state's "Certificates of Ascertainment" is⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mdue. If they miss this deadline, the electorate votes are forfeited.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mKeep in mind some of these swing states don't have strong one-party control of the state legislatures, and⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0mthere could be a strong appetite for a recount or closer scrutiny of the ballots.⁣
  [0m[31m▎[0m⁣
